{{DISPLAYTITLE: {{mp|2017 TD|6}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2017 TD|6}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Pan-STARRS]] | discovery_site = [[Haleakala Observatory|Haleakala Obs.]] | discovered = 11 October 2017
{{small|(first observed only)}} | mpc_name = {{mp|2017 TD|6}} | alt_names = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 6 | observation_arc = (8 days) | aphelion = 1.5284 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.7798 AU | semimajor = 1.1541 AU | eccentricity = 0.3243 | period = 1.24 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (453 days) | mean_anomaly = 275.44[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.7950|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 1.7198° | asc_node = 26.985° | arg_peri = 82.738° | moid = 0.00034 AU{{·}}0.13 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | dimensions = 9.9–22 [[Meter|m]]
11 m {{small|(generic at [[Geometric albedo|0.20]])}} | rotation = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 27.162{{·}}27.175 }} '''{{mp|2017 TD|6}}''' is a micro-[[asteroid]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately 10–20 meters in diameter. It was first observed by [[Pan-STARRS]] at [[Haleakala Observatory]], Hawaii, on 11 October 2017. On 19 October 2017, the asteroid transited Earth at a nominal distance of {{convert |0.001278 |AU |km mi |abbr=on |lk=on |sigfig=3 |order=flip}}, which corresponds to 0.5 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]]s (LD). On the following day it also passed near the [[Moon]] at {{convert |0.00075575 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}}. Peaking near a [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] of 18, the object was too faint to be seen—except for the largest telescopes. As of 2018, {{mp|2017 TD|6}} has a poorly determined orbit with an [[Uncertainty parameter|uncertainty]] of 6 and a short [[observation arc]] of 8 days only. Due to its small size, the asteroid is likely to remain unobserved until its next, still relatively distant approach, predicted to occur in March 2044, at a distance of {{convert |0.01358 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}} or 5.3 LD from Earth. == See also == * {{mpl|2012 TC|4}} – A similar small asteroid that passed close to the earth on 12 October 2017 == References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-10-19 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2017 TD6) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3786445 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 25 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = 2017 TD6 |work = [[Minor Planet Center]] |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2017+TD6 |accessdate = 25 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = Newfound Bus-Size Asteroid Will Zoom Safely By Earth Today |author = Steve Spaleta |publisher = Space.com |date = 19 October 2017 |url = https://www.space.com/38502-bus-size-asteroid-2017-td6-earth-flyby.html |accessdate = 25 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid Size Estimator |publisher = CNEOS NASA/JPL |url = https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/tools/ast_size_est.html |accessdate = 25 January 2018}} }} == External links == * [http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K17/K17U33.html MPEC 2017-U33 : 2017 TD6], ''[[Minor Planet Electronic Circular]]'' (MPEC) * [https://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2017/10/18/near-earth-asteroid-2017-td6-close-encounter-image-18-oct-2017 Near-Earth asteroid 2017 TD6 very close encounter: an image (18 Oct. 2017)] * [https://www.thesun.co.uk/tech/4724388/bus-sized-asteroid-narrowly-avoids-earth/ Double-decker bus sized asteroid 2017 TD6 narrowly misses Earth – the SECOND in a week], ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', 19 October 2017 * [https://watchers.news/2017/10/18/asteroid-2017-td6-to-flyby-earth-at-0-5-ld-on-october-19-2017/ Asteroid 2017 TD6 to flyby Earth at 0.5 LD on October 19, 2017], '' The Watchers'', 18 October 2017 * {{NeoDys|2017TD6}} * {{JPL small body|id=3786445}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2017 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} 2017|20171011]]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Anastasios A. Tsonis | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = <!--(filename only, i.e. without "File:" prefix)--> | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!--{{birth date |YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = [[Elefsis]], Greece | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[Atmospheric science]], [[mathematics]] | workplaces = [[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee]] | patrons = | education = B.S., [[Aristotelian University]] (1976), Ph.D., [[McGill University]] (1982) | alma_mater = | thesis_title = The evaluation of extrapolation schemes for the growth or decay of rain area and applications | thesis_url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/evaluation-of-extrapolation-schemes-for-the-growth-or-decay-of-rain-area-and-applications/oclc/427226438&referer=brief_results | thesis_year = 1982 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!--{{URL|www.example.com}}--> | footnotes = }} '''Anastasios Tsonis''' is an American atmospheric scientist and distinguished professor at the [[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee]].
==Education== Tsonis was born in the Greek city of [[Elefsis]].<ref name=about>[https://pantherfile.uwm.edu/aatsonis/www/# About Page], uwm.edu</ref> He received his BS from [[Aristotelian University]] in 1976 and his PhD from [[McGill University]] in 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www4.uwm.edu/letsci/math/people/faculty/tsonis.cfm |title=Anastasios Tsonis |work=University of Wisconsin Milwaukee Website |accessdate=10 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141015142407/http://www4.uwm.edu/letsci/math/people/faculty/tsonis.cfm |archivedate=15 October 2014 }}</ref>
==Academic career== After receiving his PhD, Tsonis became a postdoctoral fellow at the [[Atmospheric Environmental Service]] in Canada from 1982–1985. He then joined the University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=about/>
==Research== Tsonis's career began focusing on mathematical models of atmospheric processes, such as vertical wind speeds.<ref>{{cite journal | title=The weather attractor over very short timescales | author=Tsonis, Anastasios | journal=Nature | date=June 1988 | volume=333 | issue=6173 | pages=545–547 | doi=10.1038/333545a0 | bibcode=1988Natur.333..545T}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-06-29/news/8801110401_1_atmospheric-scientist-chaos-theory-edward-lorenz | title=A Calculated Guess On Weather | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=29 June 1988 | accessdate=10 October 2014 | author=Irion, Robert}}</ref>
More recently, Tsonis has become known for his research pertaining to [[global warming]], especially natural influences on global temperatures. In 2009, Tsonis, with Kyle Swanson, published a paper reporting that natural climate shifts are superimposed on the warming trend observed during the 20th century. They concluded that "a break in the global mean temperature trend from the consistent warming over the 1976/77–2001/02 period may have occurred."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Swanson|first1=Kyle L.|last2=Tsonis|first2=Anastasios A.|title=Has the climate recently shifted?|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|date=31 March 2009|volume=36|issue=6|doi=10.1029/2008GL037022|bibcode=2009GeoRL..36.6711S}}</ref> The authors also argued that "there are times when different types of natural variation in the climate synchronize, which shifts the climate to a new state",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/story.html?id=288ba340-98f9-4fbe-8412-acf920b32604 |title=From chaos, coherence |work=National Post |accessdate=16 October 2014 |author=Solomon, Lawrence }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and that this may explain the supposed cessation of warming that, according to him, began in 2001 or 2002.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/dec/29/climate-science-2009 | title=Roundup: Climate science in 2009 | work=The Guardian | date=29 December 2009 | accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref> They contend that this shift changed the climate state from "warming" to "cooling".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/269336 | title=Climate Change - Who's Fault? Or No-Fault? | work=Digital Journal | date=17 March 2009 | accessdate=10 October 2014 | author=Swaffar, Gar}}</ref> Tsonis has argued that natural factors, especially ocean currents, may contribute more to climate change than human activity, and that the Earth is "now in a period of cooling that could last up to fifty years."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.maciverinstitute.com/2010/01/uw-milwaukee-professor-predicts-50-years-of-global-cooling/ | title=UW-Milwaukee Professor Predicts 50 Years of Global Cooling | work=MacIver Institute | date=13 January 2010 | accessdate=10 October 2014 | quote=Tsonis published a paper last March that found the world goes through periods of warming and cooling that tend to last thirty years. In contrast to the vast majority of climate scientists, he says we are now in a period of cooling that could last up to fifty years.}}</ref> In 2013, he reiterated his view that this cooling trend was occurring, and might continue for the next 15 years.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/environment/climatechange/10294082/Global-warming-No-actually-were-cooling-claim-scientists.html | title=Global warming? No, actually we're cooling, claim scientists | work=The Telegraph | date=8 September 2013 | accessdate=10 October 2014 | author=Dixon, Hayley}}</ref> That year, shortly after the [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] was released, he also criticized the reliability of climate models, saying that they "don't agree with each other – and they don't agree with reality."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.foxnews.com/science/2013/09/30/un-climate-change-models-warming/ | title=UN's massive new climate report adds little explanation for 'pause' in warming | work=Fox News | date=30 September 2013 | accessdate=10 October 2014 | author=Roberts, John}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tsonis, Anastasios}} [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee faculty]] [[Category:Aristotle University of Thessaloniki alumni]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]] [[Category:Greek scientists]] [[Category:Greek emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Atmospheric scientists]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Eleusis]]

revision.comment: /* Contribution to climate change */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Nature communications → Nature Communications (2)
revision.text:
[[File:methanestorflaket.JPG|right|thumb|[[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|PMMA]] chambers used to measure methane and [[CO2|CO<sub>2</sub>]] emissions in [[Storflaket]] [[peat]] [[bog]] near [[Abisko]], northern [[Sweden]].]]
[[File:CH4.BRW.Monthly.png|300px|thumb|right|Arctic methane concentrations up to May 2018. A monthly peak of 1976.92 ppb was reached in February 2017.]]
'''Arctic methane release''' is the release of [[methane]] from seas and soils in [[permafrost]] regions of the [[Arctic]]. While a long-term natural process, it is exacerbated by [[global warming]]. This results in a [[positive feedback]] effect, as [[methane]] is itself a powerful [[greenhouse gas]].
The Arctic region is one of the many natural sources of the greenhouse gas methane.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.1175176 | title = Large-Scale Controls of Methanogenesis Inferred from Methane and Gravity Spaceborne Data | year = 2010 | last1 = Bloom | first1 = A. A. | last2 = Palmer | first2 = P. I. | last3 = Fraser | first3 = A. | last4 = Reay | first4 = D. S. | last5 = Frankenberg | first5 = C. | journal = Science | volume = 327 | pages = 322–325| pmid = 20075250 | issue = 5963 |bibcode = 2010Sci...327..322B }}</ref> Global warming accelerates its release, due to both release of methane from existing stores, and from [[methanogenesis]] in rotting [[biomass]].<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1029/2007JG000569| title = Methane production and bubble emissions from arctic lakes: Isotopic implications for source pathways and ages| year = 2008| last1 = Walter | first1 = K. M.| last2 = Chanton | first2 = J. P. |authorlink2=Jeff Chanton| last3 = Chapin | first3 = F. S.| last4 = Schuur | first4 = E. A. G.| last5 = Zimov | first5 = S. A.| journal = Journal of Geophysical Research| volume = 113| pages = G00A08 | bibcode=2008JGRG..11300A08W}}</ref> Large quantities of methane are stored in the Arctic in natural gas [[Deposition (geology)|deposits]], permafrost, and as undersea [[methane clathrate|clathrates]]. Permafrost and clathrates degrade on warming, thus large releases of methane from these sources may arise as a result of global warming.<ref name=zimov2006>{{cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.1128908|date=Jun 2006|author=Zimov, Sa|author2=Schuur, Ea|author3=Chapin, Fs 3Rd|title=Climate change. Permafrost and the global carbon budget.|volume=312|issue=5780|pages=1612–3|issn=0036-8075|pmid=16778046|journal=Science}}</ref><ref name=shakhova2005>{{cite journal|doi=10.1029/2005GL022751|title=The distribution of methane on the Siberian Arctic shelves: Implications for the marine methane cycle|year=2005|author=Shakhova, Natalia|journal=[[Geophysical Research Letters]] |volume=32|issue=9|pages=L09601|bibcode=2005GeoRL..32.9601S}}</ref> Other sources of methane include submarine [[talik]]s, river transport, ice complex retreat, submarine permafrost and decaying gas hydrate deposits.<ref name=SS07>{{Cite journal | first1=Natalia | last1=Shakhova | first2=Igor | last2=Semiletov | title=Methane release and coastal environment in the East Siberian Arctic shelf | journal=Journal of Marine Systems | volume=66 | pages=227–243 | year=2007 | doi=10.1016/j.jmarsys.2006.06.006 | issue=1–4 | postscript=<!--None-->|bibcode = 2007JMS....66..227S }}</ref>
Concentrations in the Arctic [[Atmosphere of Earth|atmosphere]] are higher by 8–10% than that in the Antarctic atmosphere. During cold glacier epochs, this gradient decreases to practically insignificant levels.<ref>Climate Change 2001: The Scientific Basis (Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, 2001)</ref> Land ecosystems are considered the main sources of this asymmetry, although it has been suggested that "the role of the [[Arctic Ocean]] is significantly underestimated."<ref name=shakhova>{{cite journal |title=Methane Anomalies in the Near-Water Atmospheric Layer above the Shelf of East Siberian Arctic Shelf |author1=N. E. Shakhova |author2=I. P. Semiletov |author3=A. N. Salyuk |author4=N. N. Bel’cheva |author5=D. A. Kosmach |journal=Doklady Earth Sciences |year=2007 |volume=415 |pages=764–768 |doi=10.1134/S1028334X07050236 |issue=5 |bibcode = 2007DokES.415..764S }}</ref> Soil temperature and moisture levels have been found to be significant variables in soil methane fluxes in [[tundra]] environments.<ref>{{Cite journal | first2 = F. | journal = Chemosphere | volume = 26 | pages = 357–368 | last2 = Chapiniii | first1 = M. | title = Environmental and biotic controls over methane flux from Arctic tundra | year = 1993 | last1 = Torn | doi = 10.1016/0045-6535(93)90431-4| bibcode = 1993Chmsp..26..357T }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | first2 = W. S. | journal = Nature | volume = 346 | pages = 160–162 | doi = 10.1038/346160a0 | last2 = Reeburgh | title = Consumption of atmospheric methane by tundra soils | first1 = S. C. | year = 1990 | last1 = Whalen | issue = 6280|bibcode = 1990Natur.346..160W }}</ref>
==Contribution to climate change==
The release of methane from the Arctic is in itself a major contributor to [[global warming]] as a result of [[polar amplification]]. Recent observations in the [[Siberian]] arctic show increased rates of methane release from the Arctic seabed.<ref name=shakhova2005 /> Land-based permafrost, also in the Siberian arctic, was estimated in 2013 to release 17 million tonnes of methane per year – a significant increase on the 3.8 million tons estimated in 2006, and estimates before then of just 0.5 million tonnes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Twice as Much Methane Escaping Arctic Seafloor|url = http://www.livescience.com/41476-more-arctic-seafloor-methane-found.html|accessdate = 2015-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| doi=10.1038/nature05040|date=Sep 2006| author=Walter, Km| author2=Zimov, Sa| author3=Chanton, Jp| author4=Verbyla, D| author5=Chapin, Fs 3Rd| title=Methane bubbling from Siberian thaw lakes as a positive feedback to climate warming| volume=443| issue=7107| pages=71–5| issn=0028-0836| pmid=16957728| journal=Nature| bibcode=2006Natur.443...71W}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Shakhova N. |author2=Semiletov I. |author3=Salyuk A. |author4=Kosmach D. |author5=Bel'cheva N. | year = 2007 | title = Methane release on the Arctic East Siberian shelf | url = http://www.cosis.net/abstracts/EGU2007/01071/EGU2007-J-01071.pdf?PHPSESSID=e | journal = [[Geophysical Research Abstracts]] | volume = 9 | issue = | page = 01071 }}</ref> This compares to around 500 million tonnes released into the atmosphere annually from all sources.<ref name=":0" />
Shakhova et al. (2008) estimate that not less than 1,400 [[gigatonne]]s (Gt) of [[carbon]] is presently locked up as methane and methane hydrates under the Arctic submarine permafrost, and 5–10% of that area is subject to puncturing by open [[talik]]s. They conclude that "release of up to 50 Gt of predicted amount of hydrate storage [is] highly possible for abrupt release at any time". That would increase the methane content of the planet's atmosphere by a factor of twelve.<ref>N. Shakhova, I. Semiletov, A. Salyuk, D. Kosmach (2008), [http://www.cosis.net/abstracts/EGU2008/01526/EGU2008-A-01526.pdf Anomalies of methane in the atmosphere over the East Siberian shelf: Is there any sign of methane leakage from shallow shelf hydrates?], [[European Geosciences Union|EGU]] General Assembly 2008, ''Geophysical Research Abstracts'', '''10''', EGU2008-A-01526</ref>
In 2008 the [[United States Department of Energy National Laboratories|United States Department of Energy National Laboratory]] system<ref>[http://newscenter.lbl.gov/feature-stories/2008/09/17/impacts-on-the-threshold-of-abrupt-climate-changes/ IMPACTS: On the Threshold of Abrupt Climate Changes], [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]] News Center, 17 September 2008</ref> identified potential [[clathrate]] destabilization in the Arctic as one of the most serious scenarios for [[abrupt climate change]], which have been singled out for priority research. The US [[Climate Change Science Program]] released a report in late December 2008 estimating the gravity of the risk of clathrate destabilization, alongside three other credible abrupt climate change scenarios.<ref>[http://www.climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap3-4/final-report/default.htm CCSP, 2008: Abrupt Climate Change. A report by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program and the Subcommittee on Global Change Research] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504113820/http://www.climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap3-4/final-report/default.htm |date=May 4, 2013 }} (Clark, P.U., [[Andrew J. Weaver|A.J. Weaver]] (coordinating lead authors), E. Brook, E.R. Cook, T.L. Delworth, and K. Steffen (chapter lead authors)). U.S. Geological Survey, Reston, VA, 459 pp.</ref>
Study findings based on NASA's CARVE mission concluded in 2015, that methane emissions in the Arctic during the cold season are higher than previously thought. The press release by JPL explained:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4804|title=Methane Emissions in Arctic Cold Season Higher Than Expected|year=2015|publisher=JPL}}</ref> {{quote|The water trapped in the soil doesn't freeze completely even below 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius). The top layer of the ground, known as the active layer, thaws in the summer and refreezes in the winter, and it experiences a kind of sandwiching effect as it freezes. When temperatures are right around 32 degrees Fahrenheit – the so-called "zero curtain" – the top and bottom of the active layer begin to freeze, while the middle remains insulated. Microorganisms in this unfrozen middle layer continue to break down organic matter and emit methane many months into the Arctic's cold period each year.}}
Hong et al. (2017) studied the seepage from large mounds of hydrates in the shallow arctic seas at Storfjordrenna, in the Barents Sea close to Svalbard. They showed that though the temperature of the sea bed has fluctuated seasonally over the last century, between 1.8 and 4.8 °C, it has only affected release of methane to a depth of about 1.6 meters. Hydrates can be stable through the top 60 meters of the sediments and the current rapid releases came from deeper below the sea floor. They concluded that the increase in flux started hundreds to thousands of years ago well before the onset of warming that others speculated as its cause, and that these seepages are not increasing due to momentary warming.<ref>Hong, Wei-Li, et al. [https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15745 "Seepage from an arctic shallow marine gas hydrate reservoir is insensitive to momentary ocean warming."] Nature Communications 8 (2017): 15745.</ref> Summarizing his research, Hong stated: {{quote|"The results of our study indicate that the immense seeping found in this area is a result of natural state of the system. Understanding how methane interacts with other important geological, chemical and biological processes in the Earth system is essential and should be the emphasis of our scientific community,"<ref>{{cite web|last1=CAGE|title=Study finds hydrate gun hypothesis unlikely|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-08-hydrate-gun-hypothesis.html|publisher=Phys.org|date=August 23, 2017}}</ref>}}
Further research by Klaus Wallmann et al. (2018) found that the hydrate release is due to the rebound of the sea bed after the ice melted. The methane dissociation began around 8,000 years ago when the land began to rise faster than the sea level, and the water as a result started to get shallower with less hydrostatic pressure. This dissociation therefore was a result of the uplift of the sea bed rather than anthropogenic warming. The amount of methane released by the hydrate dissociation was small. They found that the methane seeps originate not from the hydrates but from deep geological gas reservoirs (seepage from these formed the hydrates originally). They concluded that the hydrates acted as a dynamic seal regulating the methane emissions from the deep geological gas reservoirs and when they were dissociated 8,000 years ago, weakening the seal, this led to the higher methane release still observed today.<ref>Wallmann, K., Riedel, M., Hong, W.L., Patton, H., Hubbard, A., Pape, T., Hsu, C.W., Schmidt, C., Johnson, J.E., Torres, M.E. and Andreassen, K., 2018. Gas hydrate dissociation off Svalbard induced by isostatic rebound rather than global warming. Nature Communications, 9(1), p.83.</ref>
===Arctic sea ice=== {{Main|Arctic sea ice decline}} A 2015 study concluded that Arctic sea ice decline accelerates methane emissions from the Arctic tundra. One of the study researchers noted, "The expectation is that with further sea ice decline, temperatures in the Arctic will continue to rise, and so will [[atmospheric methane|methane]] emissions from northern wetlands."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/09/150917091306.htm|publisher=ScienceDaily|year=2015|title=Melting Arctic sea ice accelerates methane emissions}}</ref>
===Ice sheets=== A 2014 study found evidence for methane cycling below the ice sheet of the [[Russell Glacier (Greenland)|Russell Glacier]], based on subglacial drainage samples which were dominated by [[Proteobacteria]]. During the study, the most widespread surface melt on record for the past 120 years was observed in Greenland; on 12 July 2012, unfrozen water was present on almost the entire ice sheet surface (98.6%). The findings indicate that [[methanotrophs]] could serve as a biological methane sink in the subglacial ecosystem, and the region was, at least during the sample time, a source of [[atmospheric methane]]. Scaled dissolved methane flux during the 4 months of the summer melt season was estimated at 990 Mg CH4. Because the Russell-Leverett Glacier is representative of similar Greenland outlet glaciers, the researchers concluded that the Greenland Ice Sheet may represent a significant global methane source.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Molecular and biogeochemical evidence for methane cycling beneath the western margin of the Greenland Ice Sheet|year=2014|author=Markus Dieser|author2=Erik L J E Broemsen |author3=Karen A Cameron|author4=Gary M King|author5=Amanda Achberger|author6=Kyla Choquette|author7=Birgit Hagedorn|author8=Ron Sletten|author9=Karen Junge |author10=Brent C Christner |last-author-amp=yes|url=http://www.nature.com/ismej/journal/v8/n11/full/ismej201459a.html|journal=The ISME Journal |volume=8 |issue=11|doi=10.1038/ismej.2014.59 |pages=2305–2316|pmc=4992074}}</ref> A study in 2016 concluded that [[methane clathrate]]s may exist below Greenland's and Antarctica's ice sheets, based on past evidence.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2016/160107/ncomms10314/full/ncomms10314.html|title=Ice-sheet-driven methane storage and release in the Arctic |year=2016 |journal=Nature Communications |volume=7 |pages=10314 |author=Alexey Portnov|author2=Sunil Vadakkepuliyambatta|author3=Jürgen Mienert |author4=Alun Hubbard |last-author-amp=yes |doi=10.1038/ncomms10314 |pmid=26739497 |pmc=4729839 |bibcode=2016NatCo...710314P}}</ref>
==Loss of permafrost== {{main|Permafrost#Climate change effects}}
Sea ice loss is correlated with warming of Northern latitudes. This has melting effects on permafrost, both in the sea,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://e360.yale.edu/content/feature.msp?id=2081 |date=30 Oct 2008 |accessdate=14 May 2009 |title=Melting Arctic Ocean Raises Threat of 'Methane Time Bomb' |author=Susan Q. Stranahan |work=Yale Environment 360 |publisher=Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204012056/http://e360.yale.edu/content/feature.msp?id=2081 |archivedate=4 February 2009 }}</ref> and on land.<ref name=ncar2008>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucar.edu/news/releases/2008/permafrost.jsp |title=Permafrost Threatened by Rapid Retreat of Arctic Sea Ice, NCAR Study Finds |publisher=University Corporation for Atmospheric Research |date=2008-06-10 |accessdate=2008-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118170723/http://www.ucar.edu/news/releases/2008/permafrost.jsp |archivedate=2010-01-18 }}</ref> Lawrence et al. suggest that current rapid melting of the sea ice may induce a rapid melting of arctic permafrost.<ref name=ncar2008 /><ref>{{Cite journal|year=2008 |title=Accelerated Arctic land warming and permafrost degradation during rapid sea ice loss |first=David M. |last=Lawrence |first2=Andrew G. |last2=Slater |first3=Robert A. |last3=Tomas |first4=Marika M. |last4=Holland |first5=Clara |last5=Deser |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=35 |issue=11 |doi=10.1029/2008GL033985 |url=http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/ccr/dlawren/publications/lawrence.grl.submit.2008.pdf |pages=L11506 |bibcode=2008GeoRL..3511506L |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320104125/http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/ccr/dlawren/publications/lawrence.grl.submit.2008.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-20 }}</ref> This has consequential effects on methane release,<ref name=zimov2006 /> and wildlife.<ref name=ncar2008 /> Some studies imply a direct link, as they predict cold air passing over ice is replaced by warm air passing over the sea. This warm air carries heat to the permafrost around the Arctic, and melts it.<ref name=ncar2008 /> This permafrost then releases huge quantities of methane.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/12/081219-methane-siberia.html |title=Methane Bubbling Up From Undersea Permafrost? |author=Mason Inman |publisher=National Geographic News |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=14 May 2009 }}</ref> Methane release can be gaseous, but is also transported in solution by rivers.<ref name=SS07 /> ''[[New Scientist]]'' states that "Since existing models do not include feedback effects such as the heat generated by decomposition, the permafrost could melt far faster than generally thought."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20127011.500-arctic-meltdown-is-a-threat-to-humanity.html?full=true |title=Arctic Meltdown is a Threat to Humanity |last=Pearce |first=Fred |date=28 March 2009 |work=New Scientist |publisher=Reed Business Information |accessdate=2009-03-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090329075410/http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20127011.500-arctic-meltdown-is-a-threat-to-humanity.html?full=true| archivedate= 29 March 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref>
There is another possible mechanism for rapid methane release. As the Arctic Ocean becomes more and more ice free, the ocean absorbs more of the incident energy from the sun. The Arctic Ocean becomes warmer than the former ice cover and much more water vapour enters the air. At times when the adjacent land is colder than the sea, this causes rising air above the sea and an off-shore wind as air over the land comes in to replace the rising air over the sea. As the air rises, the [[dew point]] is reached and clouds form, releasing latent heat and further reinforcing the buoyancy of the air over the ocean. All this results in air being drawn from the south across the tundra rather than the present situation of cold air flowing toward the south from the cold sinking air over the Arctic Ocean. The extra heat being drawn from the south further accelerates the warming of the permafrost and the Arctic Ocean with increased release of methane.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
[[Sinkhole]]s discovered in the [[Yamal Peninsula]] in [[Siberia]], Russia beginning in July 2014 are believed by Russian researchers to have been caused by methane released due to permafrost thawing. Near the bottom of the first sinkhole, air contained unusually high concentrations of methane, according to tests conducted by the researchers.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/news/mysterious-siberian-crater-attributed-to-methane-1.15649|title=Mysterious Siberian crater attributed to methane|first=Katia|last=Moskvitch|publisher=|doi=10.1038/nature.2014.15649|journal=Nature|year=2014}}</ref> This hypothesis points to the destabilization of gas hydrates containing huge amounts of methane gas.<ref name="CAGE_2014" />
According to researchers at Norway's Centre for Arctic Gas Hydrate (CAGE), through a process called geothermal heat flux, the Siberian [[permafrost]] which extends to the seabed of the [[Kara Sea]], a section of the [[Arctic Ocean]] between the Yamal Peninsula and [[Novaya Zemlya]], is thawing. According to a CAGE researcher, Aleksei Portnov,
{{quote|"The thawing of permafrost on the ocean floor is an ongoing process, likely to be exaggerated by the global warming of the world´s oceans."|source=CAGE 2014}}
[[Methane hydrate]] is leaking in an area of at least 7500 m2. In some areas gas flares extend up to {{convert|25|meters|abbr=on}}. Prior to their research it was proposed that methane was tightly sealed into the permafrost by water depths up to {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}}. Close to the shore however, where the permafrost seal tapers to as little as {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}}, there are significant amounts of gas leakage.<ref name="CAGE_2014">{{citation |url=https://cage.uit.no/news/methane-leaking-permafrost-seal-offshore-siberia/ |title=Methane is leaking from permafrost offshore Siberia |first=Maja |last=Sojtaric |publisher=Centre for Arctic Gas Hydrate (CAGE) |location=Tromsø, Norway |accessdate=28 December 2014 |date=18 December 2014 }}</ref>
==Clathrate breakdown== {{Main|Clathrate gun hypothesis}} {{annotated image/Extinction|float=right|caption=The Permian–Triassic extinction event (the [[Great Dying]]) may have been caused by release of [[methane]] from [[clathrate]]s. An estimated 52% of marine [[genus]] became extinct, representing 96% of all marine [[species]].}}
[[Sea ice]], and the cold conditions it sustains, serves to stabilise [[methane]] deposits on and near the shoreline,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/climate-change/exclusive-the-methane-time-bomb-938932.html |title=Exclusive: The methane time bomb |author=Steve Connor |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=14 May 2009 |publisher=The Independent |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403201120/http://www.independent.co.uk/environment/climate-change/exclusive-the-methane-time-bomb-938932.html |archivedate=3 April 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> preventing the [[clathrate]] breaking down and outgassing [[methane]] into the atmosphere, causing further warming. Melting of this ice may release large quantities of [[methane]], a powerful [[greenhouse gas]] into the [[atmosphere]], causing further warming in a strong [[positive feedback]] cycle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,547976,00.html |title=A Storehouse of Greenhouse Gases Is Opening in Siberia |author=Volker Mrasek |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=17 April 2008 |accessdate=14 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501174420/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C547976%2C00.html |archivedate=1 May 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Even with existing levels of warming and melting of the Arctic region, submarine methane releases linked to [[clathrate]] breakdown have been discovered,<ref name=indep13DEC2011>Vast methane 'plumes' seen in Arctic ocean as sea ice retreats
Tuesday 13 December 2011
https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/vast-methane-plumes-seen-in-arctic-ocean-as-sea-ice-retreats-6276278.html </ref> and demonstrated to be leaking into the [[atmosphere]].<ref name=SS07 /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17625-as-arctic-ocean-warms-megatonnes-of-methane-bubble-up.html|title=As Arctic Ocean warms, megatonnes of methane bubble up|first=Michael|last=Marshall|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=is-global-warming-happening-faster-than-expected|title=Global Warming: Faster Than Expected?|first=John|last=Carey|publisher=|volume=307|issue=5|pages=50–55|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican1112-50|journal=Scientific American|year=2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=climate-change-earth-may-be-warming-faster-than-expected|title=Earth May Be Warming Even Faster Than Expected [Slide Show]|first=Mark|last=Fischetti|publisher=}}</ref> A 2011 Russian survey off the East Siberian coast found plumes wider than one kilometer releasing methane directly into the atmosphere.<ref name=indep13DEC2011/>
According to monitoring carried out in 2003/2004 by Shakhova et al., the surface layer of shelf water in the [[East Siberian Sea]] and [[Laptev Sea]] was supersaturated up to 2500% relative to then present average [[atmospheric methane]] content of 1.85 ppm. Anomalously high concentrations (up to 154 nM or 4400% supersaturation) of dissolved methane in the bottom layer of shelf water suggest that the bottom layer is somehow affected by near-bottom sources. Considering the possible formation mechanisms of such plumes, their studies indicated thermoabrasion and the effects of shallow gas or gas hydrates release.<ref name=shakhova2005 />
Research in 2008 in the Siberian Arctic has shown [[clathrate]]-derived methane being released through perforations in the seabed permafrost.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1029/2006GL027977 |title=Origin of pingo-like features on the Beaufort Sea shelf and their possible relationship to decomposing methane gas hydrates |year=2007 |author=Paull, Charles K. |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=L01603 |last2=Ussler |first2=William |last3=Dallimore |first3=Scott R. |last4=Blasco |first4=Steve M. |last5=Lorenson |first5=Thomas D. |last6=Melling |first6=Humfrey |last7=Medioli |first7=Barbara E. |last8=Nixon |first8=F. Mark |last9=McLaughlin |first9=Fiona A. |bibcode=2007GeoRL..3401603P}}</ref>
The climatic effects of a potential release of methane from global ocean clathrates may be significant on timescales of 1–100 thousand years, depending on the water temperature.<ref name=AB05>{{Cite journal | first1=David | last1=Archer | first2=Bruce | last2=Buffett | title=Time-dependent response of the global ocean clathrate reservoir to climatic and anthropogenic forcing | journal=Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems – G3 | year=2005 | accessdate=2009-05-15 | url=http://geosci.uchicago.edu/~archer/reprints/archer.2005.clathrates.pdf | doi=10.1029/2004GC000854 | volume=6 | issue=3 | pages=1–13 | postscript=<!--None--> | bibcode=2005GGG.....603002A}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Global warming|Ecology|Environment}} * [[Arctic dipole anomaly]] * [[Atmospheric methane]] * [[Clathrate gun hypothesis]] * [[Clathrate hydrate]] * [[Gas hydrate pingo]] * [[Methane chimney]] * [[Methane clathrate]] * [[Long-term effects of global warming]] * [[Permafrost Carbon Cycle]] * [[Soil respiration]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2005/12/methane-hydrates-and-global-warming/ Methane hydrates and global warming], [[RealClimate]] from December 12, 2005 * [http://www.ameg.me Arctic Methane Emergency Group] UK Based 'Arctic Methane Emergency Group' calling for [[Individual and political action on climate change|action]] on Arctic methane crisis * [http://lasthours.org Last Hours Film] Short film about potential for massive release of arctic methane * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141221175037/http://www.methanetracker.org/ Methane Tracker ] Online tools to visualize atmospheric methane releases * [http://envisionation.co.uk/index.php/arctic-methane-why-the-sea-ice-matters Film Arctic Methane: Why The Sea Ice Matters] Featuring James Hansen, Peter Wadhams, and Natalia Shakhova * [http://siberiantimes.com/science/casestudy/news/n0018-exclusive-new-pictures-inside-mystery-siberian-crater/ Exclusive new pictures INSIDE Siberian crater] Siberian Times, 2014 * [http://siberiantimes.com/science/casestudy/news/n0905-7000-underground-gas-bubbles-poised-to-explode-in-arctic/ 7,000 underground gas bubbles poised to 'explode' in Arctic] Siberian Times, 2017 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aqxbU9zOKgE Climate Change in the Arctic and Model Projections] (Video)

{{other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Black Orpheus | film name = {{Infobox name module|pt|Orfeu Negro}} | image = BlackOrpheusposter.jpg | caption = Original poster | director = [[Marcel Camus]] | screenplay = {{ubl|Marcel Camus|Jacques Viot}} | based on = ''[[Orfeu da Conceição]]''
by [[Vinicius de Moraes]] | starring = {{ubl|[[Breno Mello]]|[[Marpessa Dawn]]}} | producer = Sacha Gordine | music = {{ubl|[[Luiz Bonfá]]|[[Antônio Carlos Jobim]]}} | cinematography = [[Jean Bourgoin]] | editing = [[Andrée Feix]] | studio = {{ubl|Dispat Films (France)|Gemma (Italy)|Tupan Filmes (Brazil)}} | distributor = [[Lopert Pictures]] | country = {{Flatlist| * Brazil * France * Italy}} | released = {{film date|1959|6|12|France|df=yes}} | runtime = 107 minutes | language =[[Brazilian Portuguese]] | budget = | gross = {{USD|750,000}}"M-G-M Cashing In on Oscar Victory: ''Ben-Hur'' Gross Expected to Reach 7 Million by Week's End – ''Spartacus'' Booked", ''The New York Times'' (1923–Current file) 7 April 1960: 44. }} '''''Black Orpheus''''' ([[Brazilian Portuguese]]: ''Orfeu Negro'' {{IPA-pt|ɔɾˈfew ˈne.ɡɾu|}}) is a 1959 [[romance film|romantic]] [[tragedy]]{{cite web|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/arts/black-orpheus-6586113|title=Black Orpheus|first=Julia|last=Youssefnia|date=19 July 2007|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2002-08-16/black-orpheus-1959/|title=Black Orpheus (1959)|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=usccBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA141&q=black+orpheus+tragedy|title=Tragedy|first=Sarah|last=Dewar-Watson|date=10 June 2014|publisher=Macmillan International Higher Education|via=Google Books}}{{cite web|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/black-orpheus/review/|title=Black Orpheus|first=David|last=Parkinson|website=Empire}} film made in Brazil by French director [[Marcel Camus]] and starring [[Marpessa Dawn]] and [[Breno Mello]]. It is based on the play ''[[Orfeu da Conceição]]'' by [[Vinicius de Moraes]], which is itself an adaptation of the [[Greek mythology|Greek legend]] of [[Orpheus and Eurydice]], set in the modern context of a ''[[favela]]'' ("slum") in [[Rio de Janeiro]] during ''[[Brazilian Carnival|Carnaval]]''. The film was an international co-production among [[production company|production companies]] in Brazil, France and Italy. The film is particularly noted for its soundtrack by two Brazilian composers: [[Antônio Carlos Jobim]], whose song "[[A Felicidade]]" opens the film; and [[Luiz Bonfá]], whose "[[Manhã de Carnaval]]" and "Samba de Orfeu" have become classics of ''[[bossa nova]]''. The songs sung by the character Orfeu were dubbed by singer [[Agostinho dos Santos]].{{cite book|last=Castro|first=Ruy|title=Bossa Nova: The Story of the Brazilian Music That Seduced the World|year=1990|publisher=A Capella Books|location=Chicago|isbn=978-1-55652-494-3|pages=166–167}} Lengthy passages of the film were shot in the [[Morro da Babilônia]], a ''favela'' in the [[Leme, Rio de Janeiro|Leme]] neighbourhood of [[Rio de Janeiro]].Valladares, Licia. [http://lanic.utexas.edu/project/etext/llilas/vrp/valladares.pdf ''Social Science Representations of Favelas in Rio De Janeiro: A Historical Perspective''.]Bellos, Alex. [https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2006/jan/14/brazil.riodejaneiro.onlocationfilminspiredtravel?page=all "Movie palace"], ''[[The Guardian]]'' (14 January 2006). ==Plot== A marble Greek ''[[bas relief]]'' explodes to reveal [[black people|black]] men dancing the [[samba]] to drums in a ''[[favela]]''. Eurydice ([[Marpessa Dawn]]) arrives in Rio de Janeiro, and takes a [[Tram|trolley]] driven by Orfeu (Breno Mello). New to the city, she rides to the end of the line, where Orfeu introduces her to the station guard, Hermes (Alexandro Constantino), who gives her directions to the home of her cousin Serafina ([[Léa Garcia]]). Although engaged to Mira (Lourdes de Oliveira), Orfeu is not very enthusiastic about the upcoming marriage. The couple go to get a marriage license. When the clerk at the courthouse hears Orfeu's name, he jokingly asks if Mira is Eurydice, annoying her. Afterward, Mira insists on getting an engagement ring. Though Orfeu has just been paid, he would rather use his money to get his guitar out of the pawn shop for the carnival. Mira finally offers to loan Orfeu the money to buy her ring. When Orfeu goes home, he is pleased to find Eurydice staying next door with Serafina. Eurydice has run away to Rio to hide from a strange man who she believes wants to kill her. The man – Death dressed in a stylized skeleton costume – finds her, but Orfeu gallantly chases him away. Orfeu and Eurydice fall in love, yet are constantly on the run from both Mira and Death. When Serafina's sailor boyfriend Chico (Waldemar De Souza) shows up, Orfeu offers to let Eurydice sleep in his home, while he takes the hammock outside. Eurydice invites him to her bed. Orfeu, Mira, and Serafina are the principal members of a [[samba school]], one of many parading during [[Brazilian Carnival|Carnival]]. Serafina decides to have Eurydice dress in her costume so that she can spend more time with her sailor. A veil conceals Eurydice's face; only Orfeu is told of the deception. During the parade, Orfeu dances with Eurydice rather than Mira. Eventually, Mira spots Serafina among the spectators and rips off Eurydice's veil. Eurydice is forced once again to run for her life first from Mira, then from Death. Trapped in Orfeu's own trolley station, she hangs from a power line to get away from Death and is killed accidentally by Orfeu when he turns the power on and electrocutes her. Death tells Orfeu "Now she's mine," before knocking him out. Distraught, Orfeu looks for Eurydice at the Office of Missing Persons, although Hermes has told him she is dead. The building is deserted at night, with only a janitor sweeping up. He tells Orfeu that the place holds only papers and that no people can be found there. Taking pity on Orfeu, the janitor takes him down a large darkened spiral staircase – a reference to the mythical Orpheus' descent into the underworld – to a [[Macumba]] ritual, a regional form of the Afro-Brazilian religion [[Candomblé]]. At the gate, there is a dog named [[Cerberus]], after the three-headed dog of [[Hades]] in Greek mythology. During the ritual, the janitor tells Orfeu to call to his beloved by singing. The spirit of Eurydice inhabits the body of an old woman and speaks to him. Orfeu wants to gaze upon her, but Eurydice begs him not to lest he lose her forever. When he turns and looks anyway, he sees the old woman, and Eurydice's spirit departs, as in the Greek myth. Orfeu wanders in mourning. He retrieves Eurydice's body from the city morgue and carries her in his arms across town and up the hill toward his home, where his shack is burning. A vengeful Mira, running amok, flings a stone that hits him in the head and knocks him over a cliff to his death with Eurydice still in his arms. Two children, Benedito and Zeca – who have followed Orfeu throughout the film – believe Orfeu's tale that his guitar playing causes the sun to rise every morning. After Orfeu's death, Benedito insists that Zeca pick up the guitar and play so that the sun will rise. Zeca plays, and the sun comes up. A little girl appears, gives Zeca a single flower, and the three children dance. ==Cast== [[File:Orfeu Negro, 1959.jpg|thumb|upright|Poster by [[Helmuth Ellgaard]] for the German release]] {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} * [[Breno Mello]] as Orfeu * [[Marpessa Dawn]] as Eurydice * [[Marcel Camus]] as Ernesto * Fausto Guerzoni as Fausto * Lourdes de Oliveira as Mira * [[Léa Garcia]] as Serafina {{col-break|gap=4em}} * [[Adhemar da Silva]] as Death * Alexandro Constantino as Hermes * Waldemar De Souza as Chico * Jorge Dos Santos as Benedito * Aurino Cassiano as Zeca {{col-end}} ;Notes * Marpessa Dawn was not from Brazil, but from [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania.{{IMDb name|0206026|Marpessa Dawn}} * Breno Mello was a [[soccer]] player with no acting experience at the time he was cast as Orfeu.{{cite news|last=Hevesi|first=Dennis|title=Breno Mello, 76, Star of ''Orpheus'', Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/06/movies/06mello.html|accessdate=25 February 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 September 2008}} Mello was walking on the street in Rio de Janeiro, when director Marcel Camus stopped him and asked if he would like to be in a film.{{cite web|last=Guyot|first=Jean-François|title=Astro de ''Orfeu Negro'' conhece Cannes 46 anos apos vencer festival|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/ilustrada/ult90u50821.shtml|website=France Presse|accessdate=25 February 2012|date=17 May 2005}} * Da Silva, the actor who played Death, was a [[triple jump]]er who won two Olympic gold medals, in 1952 and 1956.{{cite web|title=Adhemar da Silva|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/da/adhemar-da-silva-1.html|website=sports-reference.com|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=13 June 2015}} * A young boy who dances across the screen playing a [[pandeiro]] grew up to win a national pandeiro-playing contest and play his instrument around the world. Currently, [[Carlinhos Pandeiro de Ouro]] teaches in Los Angeles and at California Brazil Camp. ==Awards and honors== ''Black Orpheus'' won the [[Palme d'Or]] at the [[1959 Cannes Film Festival]],{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/3471/year/1959.html |title=''Black Orpheus''|date=1959 |accessdate=15 February 2009|website=[[Festival de Cannes]]}} the 1960 [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]],{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1960|title=The 32nd Academy Awards (1960) Nominees and Winners|accessdate=27 October 2011|publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]}} the 1960 [[Golden Globe Award]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Film]] and the 1961 [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] for Best Foreign Language Film. In the last case, Brazil was credited together with France and Italy. ==Influence== ''Black Orpheus'' was cited by [[Jean-Michel Basquiat]] as one of his early musical influences,Fretz, Eric. ''Jean-Michael Basquiat: A Biography'', Greenwood Biographies, 2010, p. 5. while [[Barack Obama]] notes in his [[memoir]] ''[[Dreams from My Father]]'' (1995) that it was his mother's favorite film.Gonzalez, Ed. [http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/2008/22/barack-obama-a-story-of-race-and-politics "The House Next Door: Barack Obama: A Story of Race and Politics"], ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' (22 March 2008).Williams, Tia. [http://www.essence.com/2011/08/21/black-orpheus-marpessa-dawn/ "Vintage Vamp: Black Orpheus Star Marpessa Dawn"] ''[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]'', (21 August 2011). Obama, however, did not share his mother's preferences upon first watching the film during his first years at [[Columbia University]]: "I suddenly realized that the depiction of the childlike blacks I was now seeing on the screen, the reverse image of Conrad's dark savages, was what my mother had carried with her to Hawaii all those years before, a reflection of the simple fantasies that had been forbidden to a white, middle-class girl from Kansas, the promise of another life: warm, sensual, exotic, different."[[Peter Bradshaw|Bradshaw, Peter]], [https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2009/feb/02/barack-obama-black-orpheus "Why Obama is wrong about Black Orpheus"], ''The Guardian'', 2 February 2009. The film's soundtrack also inspired [[Vince Guaraldi]]'s 1962 album ''[[Jazz Impressions of Black Orpheus]]''. ==Remakes and adaptations== *In 1999, [[Carlos Diegues]] made ''[[Orfeu]]'' with a soundtrack featuring Brazilian singer-songwriter [[Caetano Veloso]]. The director said it was not a remake of ''Black Orpheus'' but a film based on Vinicius de Moraes' 1956 play.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/25/movies/film-review-reborn-in-a-less-romantic-rio-orpheus-seasons-samba-with-rap.html|title=FILM REVIEW; Reborn in a Less Romantic Rio, Orpheus Seasons Samba With Rap|last=Scott|first=A. O.|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en}} ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 32nd Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of French submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{IMDb title|0053146}} *{{AllRovi movie|5910}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|black_orpheus}} *{{tcmdb title|68912}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928000107/http://www.culturevulture.net/Movies/blackorpheus.htm Culture Vulture review of ''Black Orpheus''] *[https://www.criterion.com/current/posts/7-black-orpheus ''Black Orpheus''] an essay by [[David Ehrenstein]] at the [[Criterion Collection]] *[https://www.criterion.com/current/posts/1559-black-orpheus-dancing-in-the-streets ''Black Orpheus: Dancing in the Streets''] an essay by [[Michael Atkinson (writer)|Michael Atkinson]] at the [[Criterion Collection]] {{Orpheus}} {{French submission for Academy Awards}} {{Navboxes |title = Awards for ''Black Orpheus'' |list = {{AcademyAwardBestForeignLanguageFilm 1947–1960}} {{Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film}} {{Palme d'Or 1939–1959}} }} {{Portal bar|France|Brazil|Italy|Films|Musical theatre|1950s}} [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:1950s fantasy films]] [[Category:1959 films]] [[Category:BAFTA winners (films)]] [[Category:Best Foreign Language Film Academy Award winners]] [[Category:Bossa nova albums]] [[Category:Brazilian comedy films]] [[Category:Brazilian drama films]] [[Category:Brazilian films]] [[Category:Brazilian musical films]] [[Category:Films based on Greco-Roman mythology]] [[Category:Films directed by Marcel Camus]] [[Category:Films set in Rio de Janeiro (city)]] [[Category:Films shot in Rio de Janeiro (city)]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Orpheus]] [[Category:Palme d'Or winners]] [[Category:Portuguese-language films]] [[Category:Romantic fantasy films]]

revision.text:
{{short description|New Zealand's most remote group of inhabited islands}} {{about|islands of New Zealand|islands elsewhere|Chatham Island (disambiguation)}} {{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox islands | name = Chatham Islands | native_name = Rēkohu / Wharekauri | native_name_lang = Moriori / Māori | image_name = Chatham Islands from space ISS005-E-15265.jpg | image_caption = Satellite photograph of the archipelago. The two largest islands are [[Chatham Island]], followed by [[Pitt Island]] to the southeast | image_size = 250px | map_image = Chatham Islands in New Zealand (zoom).svg | map_caption = Location of the Chatham Islands in the [[Pacific Ocean]] | location = Southern Pacific Ocean | coordinates = {{coord|44|02|S|176|26|W|region:NZ_dim:100000|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = Chatham Islands | total_islands = 10 | major_islands = [[Chatham Island]], [[Pitt Island]] | area_km2 = 966 | highest_mount = | elevation_m = 299 | country = [[New Zealand]] | country_largest_city = [[Waitangi, Chatham Islands|Waitangi]] | population = 600 | population_as_of = [[2013 New Zealand census|2013 census]] | timezone1 = [[Time in New Zealand|CHAST]] | utc_offset1 = +12:45 | timezone1_DST = CHADT | utc_offset1_DST = +13:45 | website = | additional_info = }} The '''Chatham Islands''' form an [[archipelago]] in the Pacific Ocean about {{convert|800|km|round=10|abbr=out}} east of the [[South Island]] of [[New Zealand]]. It consists of about ten islands within a {{convert|40|km|adj=on}} radius, the largest of which are [[Chatham Island]] and [[Pitt Island]]. Some of these islands, once cleared for farming, are now preserved as nature reserves to [[conservation in New Zealand|conserve]] some of the unique flora and fauna. The resident population is 600 ({{as of|2013|lc=on}}).{{cite web|title=2013 Census QuickStats about a place: Chatham Islands Territory|url=http://archive.stats.govt.nz/Census/2013-census/profile-and-summary-reports/quickstats-about-a-place.aspx?url=/Census/2013-census/profile-and-summary-reports/quickstats-about-a-place.aspx&request_value=15197&tabname|publisher=[[Statistics New Zealand]]|accessdate=16 December 2017}} The islands' economy is largely dependent on conservation, tourism, farming, and fishing. The archipelago is called ''Rēkohu'' ("Misty Sun") in the indigenous [[Moriori language]], and ''Wharekauri'' in [[Māori language|Māori]]. The [[Moriori]] are the indigenous people of the Chatham Islands, and members of the [[Māori people|Māori]] [[Ngāti Mutunga]] tribe have also settled on the island. It has officially been part of New Zealand since 1842 and includes the country's easternmost point, the [[Forty-Fours]]. Local administration of the Chatham Islands is provided by the Chatham Islands Council, whose powers are similar to other [[unitary authorities]]. The islands are listed with the [[New Zealand Outlying Islands]]. The islands are an immediate part of New Zealand, but not part of any [[Regions of New Zealand|region]] or [[Territorial Authorities of New Zealand|district]], but instead ''Area Outside Territorial Authority'', like all the other outlying islands except the [[Solander Islands]]. ==Geography== {{See also|Chatham Rise}} [[File:Chatham-Islands map topo en.svg|thumb|270px|[[Topographic map]] of the Chatham Islands]] The islands are at about {{coord|43|53|S|176|31|W|}}, roughly {{convert|840|km|mi|-1}} east of [[Christchurch]], [[New Zealand]]. The nearest mainland New Zealand point to the Chatham Islands is [[Cape Turnagain]], in the [[North Island]] at a distance of {{convert|650|km|mi|-1}}. The nearest mainland city to the islands is [[Hastings, New Zealand]], located {{convert|697|km|mi|-1}} to the North-West. The two largest islands, [[Chatham Island]] and [[Pitt Island]], constitute most of the total area of {{convert|966|km2|sqmi|0}}, with a dozen scattered islets covering the rest. The islands sit on the [[Chatham Rise]], a large, relatively shallowly submerged (no more than {{convert|1000|m|ft|0|disp=or}} deep at any point) part of the [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]] continent that stretches east from near the South Island. The Chatham Islands, which emerged only within the last four million years, are the only part of the Chatham Rise showing above sea level.{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/TheBush/UnderstandingTheNaturalWorld/Ecoregions/9/en |title=Ecoregions: The Chatham Islands |accessdate=2009-02-08 |last=McGlone |first=Matt |date=21 September 2007 |work=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand |publisher= }} The islands are hilly with coasts being a varied mixture including cliffs and [[dune]]s, beaches, and lagoons. Pitt is more rugged than Chatham, although the highest point ({{convert|299|m|ft|disp=or}}) is on a plateau near the southernmost point of the main island (at {{coord|44|07|12|S|176|34|38|W|}}, {{convert|1.5|km|mi}} south of [[Lake Te Rangatapu]]).[https://www.topomap.co.nz/NZTopoMap/ci54/Lake-Te-Rangatapu/ New Zealand topographic map of Lake Te Rangatapu area] The plateau is dotted with numerous lakes and lagoons, flowing mainly from the island's nearby second highest point, [[Maungatere Hill]], at 294 metres.{{cite web|title=Chatham Islands Conservation Management Strategy|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/Documents/about-doc/role/policies-and-plans/chatham-islands-cms.pdf|publisher=Department of Conservation|accessdate=17 October 2017|page=32}} Notable are the large [[Te Whanga Lagoon]], and Huro and Rangitahi. Chatham has a number of streams, including Te Awainanga and Tuku. Chatham and Pitt are the only inhabited islands, with the remaining smaller islands being conservation reserves with restricted or prohibited access. The livelihoods of the inhabitants depend on agriculture, with the island being an exporter of coldwater [[Jasus edwardsii|crayfish]], and increasing tourism. The names of the main islands, in the order of occupation are: {| class="wikitable" |- ! English name !! Moriori name !! Māori name !! Remarks |- | [[Chatham Island]] || Rekohu || Wharekauri || |- | [[Pitt Island]] || Rangiaotea || Rangiauria || |- | [[South East Island]] || Rangatira || Rangatira || |- | The Fort || Mangere || [[Mangere Island|Mangere]] || The Māori name has supplanted the English name for this island. |- | [[Little Mangere Island|Little Mangere]] || ''Unknown'' || Tapuenuku || |- | [[Star Keys]] || Motuhope || Motuhope || |- | [[The Sisters (New Zealand)|The Sisters]] || Rangitatahi || Rangitatahi || about {{convert|16|km|mi}} north of [[Cape Pattisson (Chatham Island)|Cape Pattison]], a headland in the northwestern part of Chatham Island |- | [[Forty-Fours]] || Motchuhar || Motuhara || the easternmost point of New Zealand, about {{convert|50|km|mi}} from Chatham Island. |} ===Climate=== Chatham Islands have an [[oceanic climate]]{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weather-summary.php3?s=939870&cityname=Waitangi%2C+Northland%2C+New+Zealand&units=|title=Waitangi, Northland, New Zealand Climate Summary|publisher=Weatherbase|accessdate=11 January 2015}} characterised by a narrow temperature range and relatively frequent rainfall. Its isolated position far from any sizeable landmass renders the record temperature for main settlement Waitangi to be just {{convert|23.8|C|F}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weatherall.php3?s=939870&cityname=Waitangi%2C+Northland%2C+New+Zealand&units=|title=Waitangi, Northland, New Zealand Temperature Averages|publisher=Weatherbase|accessdate=11 January 2015}} The climate is cool, wet and windy, with average high temperatures between {{convert|15|and|20|°C|°F}} in summer, and between {{convert|5|and|10|°C|°F}} in July, the Southern Hemisphere winter. Snow is extremely rare, being recorded near sea level in July 2015 after several decades. http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/rural/282430/drought,-cyclone-then-snow-for-chathams-farms {{Weather
