revision.comment: Changing [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]] from "A seamount chain in southeastern Gulf of Alaska stretching from the Aleutian Trench in the north to Bowie Seamount," to "A seamount chain in southeastern Gulf of Alaska stretching from the Aleutian Trench in the north to Bowie Seamount" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper.js|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A seamount chain in southeastern Gulf of Alaska stretching from the Aleutian Trench in the north to Bowie Seamount}} {{Infobox Seamount | Name=Kodiak–Bowie Seamount chain | Map= [[Image:Kodiak-Bowie Seamounts.jpg|300px]] | Map caption=Map of the Kodiak-Bowie Seamount chain | Depth= | Height= | Summit = | Location= North [[Pacific Ocean]] | Group= | Coordinates = | Country =[[Canada]]/[[United States]] | Age= | Last eruption= | Discovered= | Discovered_by= | First_visit= | Translation= | Pronunciation= | Photo= | Photo caption= }}
The '''Kodiak–Bowie Seamount chain''', also called the '''Pratt–Welker Seamount chain''' and the '''Kodiak Seamounts''', is a [[seamount]] chain in southeastern [[Gulf of Alaska]] stretching from the [[Aleutian Trench]] in the north to [[Bowie Seamount]], the youngest volcano in the chain, which lies {{convert|180|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} west of the [[Queen Charlotte Islands]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]].<ref name="SE">[http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/media/backgrou/2007/pr10a_e.htm The Bowie Seamount] Retrieved on 2007-09-02</ref> The oldest volcano in the chain is the [[Kodiak Seamount]]. Although the Kodiak Seamount is the oldest extant seamount in the Kodiak-Bowie chain, the adjacent lower slope contains transverse scars indicating earlier subduction of seamounts.
The Kodiak–Bowie Seamount chain are mostly [[extinct volcano]]es that formed above the [[Bowie hotspot]]. This is a 100-to-150-km-wide morphological swell presumably of thickened hotspot generated crust, although there are no seismic refraction data across the swell to define crustal thickness. The crest of one such peak, [[Patton Seamount]] originally formed off [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] state as a submerged volcano 33 million years ago. Over time, as the Pacific Plate moved steadily northwest, Patton Seamount was carried off the Bowie hotspot and into the Gulf of Alaska. New volcanoes were formed one after another over the hotspot, creating the Kodiak–Bowie Seamount chain.
Explorations of the Kodiak–Bowie Seamount chain have shown that despite the fact that most of the seamounts were created by the Bowie hotspot, all are unique in their size, shape, and volcanic features. The seamounts teem with deep-sea [[coral]]s, [[sponge]]s, and [[fish]]. Recent expeditions to these seamounts using manned submersibles and ROVs have discovered many marine species and have greatly expanded the knowledge of the range of deep sea corals in this region. For example, the [[Bowie Seamount]] is a biologically rich area with a dynamic and productive ecosystem. Because of this unique biological rich area, Bowie Seamount was declared a [[Marine Protected Area|Pilot Marine Protected Area]] on December 8, 1998.<ref>[http://www.pac.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/oceans/mpa/bowie/default_e.htm Bowie Seamount Marine Protected Area] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301053819/http://www.pac.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/oceans/mpa/bowie/default_e.htm |date=2009-03-01 }}</ref>
The Kodiak–Bowie seamount chain is at the northern [[triple junction]] between the [[Pacific Plate|Pacific]], [[North American Plate|North American]], and [[Juan de Fuca Plate|Juan de Fuca]] plates. Available age determinations on Kodiak and Giacomini Seamounts give an approximate average rate of movement along the chain of {{convert|6.5|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} per year.
==Volcanoes==
Volcanoes in the chain include:
*[[Kodiak Seamount]] (24 m.y. old)<ref name="SI">[http://www.oceanexplorer.noaa.gov/explorations/04alaska/background/volcanic/volcanic.html NOAA Ocean Explorer: Gulf of Alaska 2004] Retrieved on 2007-09-02</ref> *[[Giacomini Seamount]] (21 m.y. old)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Pratt Seamount]] (age unknown)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Welker Seamount]] (15 m.y. old)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Dickens Seamount]] (~4 m.y. old)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Denson Seamount]] (18 .m.y. old)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Durgin Seamount]] *[[Brown Seamount]] *[[Quinn Seamount]] *[[Surveyor Seamount]] *[[Peirce Seamount]] *[[Hodgkins Seamount]] *[[Bowie Seamount]] (>0.7 m.y. old)<ref name="SI"/> *[[Tuzo Wilson Seamounts]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = LONGi Green Energy Technology, formerly X'ian Longi Silicon Materials | logo = Longi Silicon Materials logo.png | type = | ISIN = | foundation = February 14, 2000 | location = HQ in [[Xi'an]], [[Shaanxi]], China: Factories in China, India, Malaysia | key_people = Dr. Li Hua, VP of R&D,
LONGi Solar;
Li Wenxue, President,
LONGi Solar | num_employees = | revenue = | operating_income = | industry = [[Photovoltaics]] | homepage = {{URL|http://en.longi-silicon.com/}} }} '''LONGi Green Energy Technology''', formerly '''Xi'an Longi Silicon Materials Corporation''', is one of the six major Chinese manufacturers of [[photovoltaics]] and a developer of solar projects. Longi is the world largest manufacturer of [[monocrystalline silicon wafer]]s and is listed on the [[Shanghai Stock Exchange]]. ==History== The company was founded February 14, 2000 as Xi'an LONGi Silicon Materials Corporation, with its corporate headquarters in [[Xian, China]]. It changed its name in February 2017 to LONGi Green Energy Technology Co Ltd. to better reflect its wider manufacturing scope after its acquisition of LERRI. It also dropped the Xi'an location as part of the name.[https://www.pv-tech.org/news/longi-changes-name Osborne, M. LONGi changes name. PVTech. Feb 23, 2017 12:38 PM GMT. Accessed February 28, 2018.] === Subsidiaries and acquisistions=== * LERRI Solar Technology Co., Ltd., (a.k.a. LERRI Photovoltaic Technology, also LERRI Solar), was acquired by LONGi.[http://www.lerri.com/ LERRI home page, default language is Mandarin Chinese; English available] * LONGi Solar ==Operations== LONGI Silicon Materials is engaged in the research, manufacture and distribution of monocrystalline ingots. It is the world's largest silicon single crystal manufacturer. It has rapidly broken world solar efficiency records three times within five months.[https://renewablesnow.com/news/longi-green-brings-mono-c-si-perc-cell-record-to-236-603359/ Longi Green brings mono c-Si PERC cell record to 23.6%. Renewables Now. February 28, 2018. Accessed February 28, 2018.] Fast Company listed Xi'an LONGi Silicon Materials one among "Most Innovative Companies 2013" "For supplying the solar industry with high-quality silicon wafers at low cost."[https://www.fastcompany.com/company/xian-longi-silicon-materials-co Most Innovative Companies 2013. Fast Company.] LONGi Solar, a subsidiary of LONGI Green Energy Technology, recently achieved a new industry record with 23.6% conversion efficiency with its P-type monocrystalline PERC ([[Crystalline silicon|passivated emitter rear cell]]) solar cells, toward which an increasing number of manufacturers worldwide are migrating.[https://www.pv-tech.org/news/longi-hits-record-23.6-conversion-efficiency-for-mono-perc-solar-cells Kenning, T. LONGi hits record 23.6% conversion efficiency for mono PERC solar cells. PVTech, Feb 28, 2018 4:44 AM GMT. Accessed 2/28/2018.][https://renewablesnow.com/news/longi-green-brings-mono-c-si-perc-cell-record-to-236-603359/ Longi Green brings mono c-Si PERC cell record to 23.6%. Renewables Now. February 28, 2018. Accessed February 28, 2018.] The technique involves taking a silicon wafer, typically 1 to 2 mm thick, and making a multitude of parallel, transverse slices across the wafer, creating a large number of slivers that have a thickness of 50 micrometres and a width equal to the thickness of the original wafer. These slices are rotated 90 degrees, so that the surfaces corresponding to the faces of the original wafer become the edges of the slivers. The result is to convert, for example, a 150 mm diameter, 2 mm-thick wafer having an exposed silicon surface area of about 175 cm2 per side into about 1000 slivers having dimensions of 100 mm × 2 mm × 0.1 mm, yielding a total exposed silicon surface area of about 2000 cm2 per side. The electrical doping and contacts that had been on the face of the wafer are now located at the edges of the sliver, rather than at the front and rear as in the case of conventional wafer cells, as a result of this rotation. This results in making the cell sensitive on both sides, from both the front and rear of the cell (a property known as ''bifaciality'').{{Cite web| url=http://solar.anu.edu.au/research/sliver.php|title=Sliver Technology Research at the Australian National University}} Such results need to be certified by a reliable and trusted external agency, and this accomplishment has been analyzed and certified by China's National Center of Supervision and Inspection on Solar Photovoltaic Product Quality (CPVT). LONGi claimed in October 2017 that they had achieved the record for a monocrystalline solar cell with a conversion efficiency (23.6%) higher than previously thought possible for a PERC cell. In early 2018 they announced a new efficiency record of 23.6%.{{cn|date=March 2018}} In December 2017, LONGi reported a record bifaciality reading of 82.15% for its ‘Hi-MO2’ mono PERC bifacial module. The company's strategic plan is to triple to 45GW by 2020 its capacity to produce monocrystalline ingots and wafers. Longi Silicon is a member of the [[Silicon Module Super League]] (SMSL), which had been a group of big-six c-Si module suppliers in the solar PV industry today until Longi was admitted.http://www.pv-tech.org/editors-blog/silicon-module-super-league-big-six-to-reach-50-global-market-share-in-2016 The other six members of the SMSL group are [[Canadian Solar]], [[Hanwha Q CELLS]], [[JA Solar]], [[Jinko Solar]], [[Trina Solar]], and [[GCL-Poly|GCL]]. Longi Silicon has been listed on the [[Shanghai Stock Exchange]] (security code: 601012) since April 2012.[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?capId=112691838 Bloomberg] LONGi has been called the fastest growing PV manufacturer in the industry. LONGi annual revenue in 2013 was derived entirely from selling around US$330 million of mono c-Si wafers, but by 2016 that annual revenue had skyrocketed to approximately US$1.67 billion. That was a nearly 94% increase over the 2015 fiscal year, which had itself generated a revenue growth of around 61% over the year before.[https://www.pv-tech.org/editors-blog/longi-is-the-fastest-growing-pv-manufacturer-in-the-industry Osborne, M. LONGi is the fastest growing PV manufacturer in the industry. PV-Tech. In Editors' Blog, Manufacturing, Fab & Facilities, Materials, Cell Processing, Modules, Markets & Finance, Companies, Financial & Legal. Apr 01, 2017 2:29 PM BST. Accessed 2/23/2018.] LONGi has plants in China[http://www.rechargenews.com/solar/868798/xian-longi-to-invest-usd-126m-in-100mw-china-pv-plan Xi'an Longi to invest $126m in 100MW China PV plan. Publicover, B. ReCharge. 30 September 2015. Updated 28 September 2016. Accessed February 28, 2010.], India[http://www.rechargenews.com/solar/868798/xian-longi-to-invest-usd-126m-in-100mw-china-pv-plan Xi'an Longi to invest $126m in 100MW China PV plan. Publicover, B. ReCharge. 30 September 2015. Updated 28 September 2016. Accessed February 28, 2010.][http://www.rechargenews.com/solar/868822/solar-power-deals-and-company-news Deals and company news from the global solar sector this week. Recharge: Solar Power Deals & Company News. 21 September 2015. Updated 28 September 2015. Accessed February 28, 2018.], and Malaysia, and has acquired production facilities from other companies, including from US manufacturer SunEdison.[http://www.rechargenews.com/solar/867786/sunedison-sells-malaysia-factory-closes-texas-poly-plant SunEdison sells Malaysia factory, closes Texas poly-plant. Lee, A. ''RechargeNews''. 18 February 2016. Updated 28 September 2016. Accessed February 28, 2018.] ''See [[SunEdison]]'''.''''' However, Photon.Info reports that Longi Green Energy is mulling an open manufactory in the USA.[https://www.photon.info/en/news/longi-green-energy-mulling-open-manufactory-usa-bloomberg Photon.Info. 18/11/2017 - 20:52.][https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-15/china-solar-manufacturer-longi-mulls-u-s-plant-as-tariffs-loom Eckhouse, B. Chinese Solar Maker Longi Mulling U.S. Plant as Tariffs Loom. November 15, 2017, 4:37 PM EST Updated on November 16, 2017, 12:01 AM EST. Accessed February 28, 2018] Further, in a lengthy article in ''PV Magazine'' Longi Silicon and Zhonghuan Semiconductor announce their shared plans for over 10GW of new expansion of additional capacity increases for their mono-crystalline products. Additionally, Longi and ET Solar announced on 25 July, 2017, the establishment of their joint venture to explore overseas markets.[https://www.pv-magazine.com/2016/08/02/longi-silicon-and-zhonghuan-semiconductor-announce-new-expansions-with-over-10gw-of-new-capacity-planned_100025635/ Cao, Z. Longi Silicon and Zhonghuan Semiconductor announce new expansions with over 10GW of new capacity planned. PV Magazine. August 2, 2016. Visited March 7, 2018.] In March 2018, LONGi announced an agreement to develop a major solar manufacturing hub in Saudi Arabia to support the Kingdom’s plans to install 200GW of solar power plants in Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (KSA). Their ‘Solar-for-Solar” strategy for this development is historic in that it avoids the long smokestack criticism by "building the manufacturing plants that would be powered entirely by solar energy to provide the lowest manufacturing carbon footprint."[https://www.pv-tech.org/news/longi-signs-agreement-to-develop-major-solar-manufacturing-hub-in-saudi-ara Osborne, M. LONGi set for agreement to develop major solar manufacturing hub in Saudi Arabia. May 25, 2018. PV Tech, accessed 5/29/2018] == Products == * P/N-type [[Mono-crystalline silicon wafer]] * P/N-type Mono-crystalline ingots * Bifacial solar cells == External links == * [http://www.en.longi-solar.com Longi Green Energy Technology] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Solar energy companies of China]] [[Category:Photovoltaics manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of China]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 2006]] [[Category:Renewable resource companies established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in China]] [[Category:Energy in China]] [[Category:Science and technology in the People's Republic of China]] [[Category:Silicon photonics]] [[Category:Silicon wafer producers]] [[Category:Crystals]] [[Category:Solar power in China]]

[[File:Hawaii Locator Map.PNG|right|250px|thumb|Map of Hawaii|alt=Map of several islands]] The islands of Hawaii, situated in the [[Pacific Ocean]], rarely experience [[tornado]]es, averaging about one per year. The state ranks as the 48th most active in terms of touch downs, with 40 confirmed tornadoes since 1950. None of these tornadoes have caused loss of life and none exceeded F2 intensity.<ref name="NWSList"/> This list of tornadoes in the state is likely incomplete, as official records date back only to 1950 for tornadoes in the United States, and Hawaii did not become a state until August 1959.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Event Report Archive|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~storms}}</ref>
The most costly tornado occurred on January 28, 1971. Although the intensity of it is unknown, damages from the tornado were estimated at $2.5 million.<ref name="NWSList">{{cite web|author=National Weather Service in Honolulu, Hawaii|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=February 12, 2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Tornadoes from 1/1/1950 - 10/31/2008|url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/pages/hawaii_tornadoes.php}}</ref> The largest outbreak of tornadoes took place during a two-day span, starting on January 27, 1971 and ending the following day. During this event, three tornadoes were confirmed and two others were reported.<ref name="NWS Summaries January 1971"/><ref name="NewsRptJan28"/>
==1950–1974== *March 19, 1955: Two tornadoes of unknown intensity touched down in [[Hawaii County, Hawaii|Hawaii County]]. The first tornado tracked for roughly {{convert|1|mi|km}} while the second was briefly on the ground.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27686}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27687}}</ref> *January 21, 1957: A tornado of unknown intensity touched down in [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|Honolulu County]]; it tracked for {{convert|3|mi|km}} and caused an estimated $25,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27688}}</ref> *February 28, 1963: a brief tornado with a width of {{convert|100|yd|m}} touched down in Honolulu County, causing an estimated $25,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27689}}</ref> *March 27, 1963: A brief tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Honolulu County, injuring one person and causing an estimated $25,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27690}}</ref> *September 22, 1965: A brief tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Honolulu County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27691}}</ref> *April 22, 1967: A brief tornado of unknown intensity touched down in [[Maui, Hawaii|Maui]], causing $2,500 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27692}}</ref> *December 17, 1967: A tornado of unknown intensity touched down in [[Kauai, Hawaii|Kauai]]; tracking for {{convert|3|mi|km}}, the tornado caused an estimated $250,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27693}}</ref> *January 27, 1971: The United States Weather Bureau reported that a tornado likely touched down on [[Oahu]] for roughly {{convert|.5|mi|km}}, causing $100,000 in damages. The tornado destroyed three barns and damaged 18 homes along its path, some of which were moved off their foundations.<ref name="NWS Summaries January 1971">{{cite book|author=Various Writers|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|year=1971|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Climatological Data: January 1971|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=XteKmAff658C&pg=PT170&lpg=PT170&dq=Kailua-Kona+January+tornado+1971&source=bl&ots=KZvrNBpTOC&sig=kRQosjxg5vtPUpQGVS36P0zyQbs&hl=en&ei=8210SoCtD52Ctgfa1dGWCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref> *January 28, 1971: A tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Honolulu County and tracked for {{convert|2|mi|km}}, causing $250,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27694}}</ref> A second, stronger tornado,<ref name="KK1971"/> forming as a large [[waterspout]], moved onshore<ref name="NewsRptJan28"/> into Hawaii County, causing $2.5 million in damages and injured four people.<ref name="KK1971">{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27695}}</ref> The tornado struck the resort town of [[Kailua-Kona, Hawaii|Kailua-Kona]], overturning cars, some of which were blown into ditches,<ref name="NewsRptJan28"/> uprooting trees and severely damaging buildings.<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff Writer|publisher=''St. Petersburg Times''|date=January 29, 1971|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Weather: Hawaii|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Rs0NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tHUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3666,6616297&dq=hawaii+tornado}}</ref> Winds in the tornado were estimated to have exceeded {{convert|100|mph|km/h}}, making it either a high-end F1 or low-end F2 tornado.<ref name="NewsRptJan28">{{cite web|author=Sharie Shima|publisher=KHNL|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=The Winter Storm of 1971|url=http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=5093099}}</ref> In all, the tornado destroyed 21 buildings, including a six-story steel hotel.<ref name="NewsRptJan28"/> Several buildings had their roofs torn off by the storm. On Maui, severe storms also caused flooding that forced the evacuation of numerous residents.<ref>{{cite web|author=United Press International|publisher=''The Bulletin''|date=January 29, 1971|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Stormy, cold weather batters much of U.S.|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C48SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JfcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3385,4867133&dq=hawaii+tornado}}</ref> Two other tornadoes were also reported during the day; however, it is unknown if they were confirmed.<ref name="NewsRptJan28"/> *June 15, 1971: A tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Honolulu County; it tracked for {{convert|1|mi|km}} and caused $25,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27696}}</ref> *December 18, 1971: A tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Kauai and tracked for {{convert|3|mi|km}} without causing damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27697}}</ref> *December 31, 1971: A brief tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Kauai, causing no damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27698}}</ref> *May 27, 1973: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Hawaii County without causing damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27699}}</ref>
==1975–1999== *November 26, 1975: An F0 tornado touched down somewhere in the state and tracked for {{convert|2|mi|km}} without causing damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27700}}</ref> *November 20, 1978: A brief tornado of unknown intensity touched down in Hawaii County, causing $300 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F? Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27701}}</ref> *March 20, 1980: A brief F1 tornado touched down in Hawaii County, causing $300 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F1 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27702}}</ref> *February 11, 1982: Two F2 tornadoes touched down in Honolulu County, each causing $250,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F2 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27703}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F2 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27704}}</ref> *March 18, 1982: An F2 tornado touched down in Honolulu, causing $250,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F2 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27705}}</ref> *November 24, 1982: [[Hurricane Iwa]], one of the worst storms to impact the state of Hawaii, reportedly produced a few tornadoes on Oahu.<ref name="mwl">{{cite web|author=Mariners Weather Log|year=1983|title=Hurricane Iwa|accessdate=August 1, 2009|url=http://members.aol.com/Rosendalhe/hurrican1.htm}}</ref> *September 23, 1983: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Honolulu County, causing $2,500 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27706}}</ref> *September 26, 1985: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Honolulu County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27707}}</ref> *April 3, 1986: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Hawaii County, causing $2,500 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27708}}</ref> *May 13, 1986: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Honolulu County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27709}}</ref> *March 25, 1988: A brief F1 tornado touched down in Hawaii County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F1 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27710}}</ref> *March 26, 1988: A brief F1 tornado touched down in Hawaii County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F1 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27711}}</ref> *February 11, 1989: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Honolulu County, causing $2,500 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~27712}}</ref>
==2000–present== *March 24, 2002: A brief F0 tornado touched down in [[Anahola, Hawaii|Anahola, Kauai]]. The tornado first formed in the Anahola Valley and skipped along a {{convert|1|mi|km}} path, ending in Moloaa Valley. Along the track, several sheds were destroyed, numerous trees were snapped and six homes sustained roof and wall damage. Damages from the tornado amounted to $60,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2002|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~454023}}</ref> *June 7, 2003: A brief F0 tornado touched down roughly {{convert|3|mi|km}} northeast of [[Mililani, Hawai'i|Mililani, Honolulu]]. A meteorologist from the National Weather Service spotted the tornado and reported that it was tracking towards [[Pearl City, Hawaii|Pearl City]]; however, the tornado dissipated before causing any damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2003|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~491380}}</ref> *January 25, 2004: A brief F0 tornado touched down roughly {{convert|3|mi|km}} northwest of [[Waipahu, Hawaii|Waipahu, Honolulu]]; no damage was reported in relation to the tornado.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~530439}}</ref> *February 7, 2004: A brief F0 tornado touched down roughly {{convert|3|mi|km}} east of [[Aiea, Hawaii|Aiea, Honolulu]]; no damage was reported in relation to the tornado.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~530453}}</ref> *February 27, 2004: An F0 tornado tracked for {{convert|5|mi|km}}, starting roughly {{convert|2|mi|km}} southeast of [[Pahala, Hawaii]]. No structural damage occurred along the path; however, numerous trees were downed and several power poles were snapped.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~530466}}</ref> *January 8, 2005: An F0 tornado touched down in [[Waimea, Kauai County, Hawaii|Waimea, Kauai]] and tracked east for {{convert|5|mi|km}}. Along the tornado's path, a carport was damaged and numerous trees were downed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~570488}}</ref> *December 4, 2005: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Aiea, Honolulu, downing several trees and damaging the roof of a home. One tree also fell on a truck.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2006|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~570638}}</ref> *March 23, 2006: A brief F0 tornado touched down in Kaumalapau Harbor, Maui. The tornado flipped over a construction trailer and carried it for about ten feet, damaged an adjacent small building, and snapped a power pole.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2006|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~608892}}</ref> *March 25, 2006: A brief F0 tornado touched down roughly {{convert|2|mi|km}} west of [[Haiku, Hawaii|Haiku, Maui]]. No damage was reported in relation to it.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2006|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: F0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~608897}}</ref> *September 23, 2008: A brief EF0 tornado touched down about {{convert|1|mi|km}} northeast of [[Lanai Airport]] on Lanai. No damage was reported in relation to it.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2008|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: EF0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~739730}}</ref> *December 13, 2008: A brief EF0 tornado touched down in [[Pakala Village, Hawaii|Pakala Village, Kauai]], causing only minor crop damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stuart Hinson|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2009|accessdate=August 1, 2009|title=Hawaii Event Report: EF0 Tornado|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~744478}}</ref> *February 11, 2009: Two tornadoes touched down on Oahu in Hawaii. At 12:50 pm local time, the first tornado touched down near a quarry, damaging nearby buildings. The tornado moved through a golf course next, throwing a utility cart about 50 to 60 ft. The tornado lifted at 1:10 pm, 20 minutes after it touched down. Numerous trees were damaged throughout the tornado's mile long path. Following an assessment by the National Weather Service, the tornado was rated as an EF1. During the assessment of the tornado, another weaker tornado was discovered to the northeast. The tornado touched down in a construction site and damaged dust barriers. The second tornado was on the ground for about ten minutes and traveled less than half a mile. The National Weather Service rated the tornado as a low-end EF0.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Weather Service in Honolulu, Hawaii |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |date=February 20, 2009 |accessdate=August 1, 2009 |title=Kapolei Tornadoes on February 11, 2009 Rated EF0 and EF1 |url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/data/HFO/PNSHFO.0902202319 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eoGvGHOl?url=http://www.prh.noaa.gov/data/HFO/PNSHFO.0902202319 |archivedate=February 23, 2009 |df= }}</ref> *May 2, 2011: During a massive thunderstorm, twin waterspouts appeared off the southeast coast of O'ahu at 5:50pm, moving slowly westward and dissipating after about 12 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|author=Leila Fujimori|publisher=Honolulu Star Advertiser|date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=December 5, 2013|title=Storm unleashes waterspouts, hail and thunderstorms|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/20110503_Storm_unleashes_waterspouts_hail.html}}</ref> *March 9, 2012: A tornadic [[waterspout]] associated with a supercell thunderstorm moved ashore on Lanikai Beach, Oahu at 7:10 AM. The tornado, rated an EF-0, tracked inland for 1.5 miles, reaching the Enchanted Lakes subdivision of Kailua. {{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} *April 23, 2015 – An EF0 tornado touched down near [[ʻEwa Beach, Hawaii|ʻEwa Beach]] and dissipated without causing damage.<ref>{{cite report|work=National Weather Service Office in Honolulu, Hawaii|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2015|accessdate=January 14, 2016|title=Hawaii Event Report: EF0 Tornado|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=565974}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Climate of Hawaii]] *[[List of Hawaii hurricanes]] *[[2012 Hawaii hailstorm]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hawaii tornadoes}} [[Category:Lists of tornadoes in the United States]] [[Category:Climate of Hawaii|Tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Hawaii| ]] [[Category:Hawaii-related lists|Tornadoes]]

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on Vaccinium

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of Lepidoptera that feed on ''Vaccinium''}} '''''[[Vaccinium]]''''' [[species]] are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species, including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on ''Vaccinium''
* [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora glitzella|C. glitzella]]'' – only on [[lingonberry]] (''V. vitis-idaea'') *** ''[[Coleophora idaeella|C. idaeella]]'' – only on lingonberry (''V. vitis-idaea'') *** ''[[Coleophora murinella|C. murinella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora uliginosella|C. uliginosella]]'' – only on [[bog bilberry]] (''V. uliginosum'') *** ''[[Coleophora vacciniivorella|C. vaccinivorella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora vitisella|C. vitisella]]'' – only on lingonberry (''V. vitis-idaea'')
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Vaccinium'' and other plants
* [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora plumbella|C. plumbella]]'' – recorded on bog bilberry (''V. uliginosum'') *** ''[[Coleophora vacciniella|C. vacciniella]]'' * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Chionodes viduella]]'' – recorded on bog bilberry (''V. uliginosum'') * [[Geometridae]] ** ''[[Alcis repandata]]'' (mottled beauty) ** ''[[Chloroclysta truncata]]'' (common marbled carpet) ** ''[[Crocallis elinguaria]]'' (scalloped oak) ** ''[[Ectropis crepuscularia]]'' (engrailed) ** ''[[Epirrita autumnata]]'' (autumnal moth) ** ''[[Eupithecia succenturiata]]'' (bordered pug) – recorded on [[bilberry]] (''V. myrtillus'') ** ''[[Eupithecia vulgata]]'' (common pug) – recorded on bilberry (''V. myrtillus'') ** ''[[Itame argillacearia]]'' (blueberry spanworm) – recorded on [[lowbush blueberry]] (''V. angustifolium'') and others ** ''[[Hemithea aestivaria]]'' (common emerald) ** ''[[Odontopera bidentata]]'' (scalloped hazel) – recorded on bilberry (''V. myrtillus'') * [[Noctuidae]] ** ''[[Diarsia mendica]]'' (ingrailed clay) ** ''[[Diarsia rubi]]'' (small square-spot) ** ''[[Melanchra persicariae]]'' (dot moth) – recorded on bilberry (''V. myrtillus'') ** ''[[Orthosia gothica]]'' (Hebrew character) – recorded on bilberry (''V. myrtillus'') ** ''[[Xestia c-nigrum]]'' (setaceous Hebrew character) * [[Pyralidae]] ** ''[[Endotricha flammealis]]'' * [[Saturniidae]] ** ''[[Pavonia pavonia]]'' (emperor moth)
== External links == *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Vaccinium&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Vaccinium''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Vaccinium]] [[Category:Vaccinium|+Lepidoptera]]

Minahan, p.5 (2010) |- |{{flag|Albania}} || [[Olive]] || ''Olea europaea'' || [[File:Olea europea 3.jpg|90px]] ||{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jfrWCQAAQBAJ|title=The Complete Guide to National Symbols and Emblems [2 Volumes]|last=Minahan|first=James|date=2009-12-23|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313344978|page=302|language=en}} |- |{{flag|Antigua and Barbuda}} || [[Bucida buceras|Whitewood]] || ''[[Bucida buceras]]'' || [[File:Starr 080530-4639 Bucida buceras.jpg|90px]] ||{{cite web|title=Our National Symbols|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.gov.ag/country_profile/national_symbols.php|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Antigua and Barbuda|accessdate=15 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101195400/http://www.foreignaffairs.gov.ag/country_profile/national_symbols.php|archivedate=1 January 2013|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TnItHSAgevMC|title=Antigua and Barbuda|last=Kras|first=Sara Louise|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|isbn=9780761425700|page=14|language=en}} |- |{{flag|Argentina}} || [[Erythrina crista-galli|Ceibo]] and [[Schinopsis balansae|Red Quebracho]] || ''Erythrina crista-galli'', ''Schinopsis balansae'' || [[File:Erythrina crista-galli 2-3.jpg|90px]]

|accessdate=2011-06-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ambiente.gov.ar/?aplicacion=normativa&IdNorma=795&IdSeccion=0|title=Declárase "Arbol Forestal Nacional" al (Schinopsis Balansea Engl) "Quebracho colorado chaqueño"|language=Spanish |publisher=Secretaría de Ambiente y Desarrollo Sustentable de la Nación|date=1956-08-21 |accessdate=2012-02-25}} |- |{{flag|Australia}} || [[Golden Wattle]] ||''Acacia pycnantha'' || [[File:Acacia pycnantha Golden Wattle.jpg|90px]] ||{{Cite web|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/emblems/aust.emblem.html|title=Floral emblems of Australia, Golden Wattle|website=anbg.gov.au|access-date=2015-10-02}} |- |{{flag|Bahamas}} || [[Lignum Vitae]] || ''[[Guaiacum sanctum]]'' || [[File:Guaiacum sanctum.jpg|90px]] ||{{cite web |url=http://www.thebahamasguide.com/facts/holidays.htm |title=National Symbols of the Bahamas |work=Bahamas Facts and Figures |publisher=TheBahamasGuide |accessdate=2009-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091221042937/http://www.thebahamasguide.com/facts/holidays.htm |archivedate=2009-12-21 |df= }}{{Cite page.title: List of rivers of the Republic of the Congo

revision.comment: /* References */HTTP→HTTPS for [[United Nations]], per [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/Bender the Bot 8|BRFA 8]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
This is a '''list of rivers in the Republic of the Congo'''. This list is arranged by [[Drainage basin]], with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name.
==[[Atlantic Ocean]]== *[[Ogooué River]] **[[Ngounie River]] **[[Ivindo River]] ***[[Djadie River]] ***[[Djoua River]] ***[[Aïna River]] **[[Letili River]] *[[Nyanga River]] *[[Kouilou-Niari River]] **[[Louésse River]] *[[Chiloango River]] *[[Congo River]] **[[Djoué River]] **[[Lefini River]] **[[Nkéni River]] **[[Alima River]] ***[[Lékéti River]] **[[Likouala River]] ***[[Kouyou River]] ***[[Lengoué River]] ***[[Mambili River]] **[[Sangha River]] ***[[Dja River]] (Ngoko River) **[[Likouala aux Herbes River]] **[[Ubangi River]] ***[[Motaba River]] ***[[Ibenga River]]
==References==
*[https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/congo.pdf United Nations 2004] *[http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/index.html GEOnet Names Server]

page.title: List of species used in bonsai

revision.comment: Mentions of Ficus retusa as a species used in bonsai seem erroneous. It is probable that these mentions actually refer to the species Ficus microcarpa.

This is an alphabetical listing of '''wort plants''', meaning plants that employ the syllable ''wort'' in their English-language common names.
According to the [[Oxford English Dictionary]]'s Ask Oxford site, "A word with the suffix ''-wort'' is often very old. The [[Old English]] word was ''wyrt'', from [[Proto-Indo-European]] origins that connect it to ''root''. It was often used{{By whom|date=October 2018}} in the names of [[herb]]s and [[plant]]s that had medicinal uses, the first part of the word denoting the complaint against which it might be specially efficacious. By the middle of the 17th-century ''-wort'' was beginning to fade from everyday use.<ref name="askoxford">{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050205000955/http://www.askoxford.com/worldofwords/wordfrom/plants/?view=print |date=February 5, 2005 |title=World of Words: A word about some useful plants}}</ref>
The ''Naturalist Newsletter'' states, "''Wort'' derives from the Old English ''wyrt'', which simply meant ''plant''. The word goes back even further, to the common ancestor of English and German, to the Germanic ''wurtiz''. ''Wurtiz'' also evolved into the modern German word ''Wurzel'', meaning ''root''."<ref name="natchez">[http://www.backyardnature.net/n/03/031221.htm Conrad, Jim, ''Natchez Naturalist Newsletter'', December 21, 2003]</ref>
==''Wort'' plants==
:Adderwort, Adder's wort - ''[[Persicaria bistorta]]''. :American lungwort - ''[[Mertensia virginica]]''. :Asterwort - Any composite plant of the family [[Asteraceae]]. :Awlwort - ''[[Subularia aquatica]]''. The plant bears awl-shaped leaves. :Banewort - ''[[Ranunculus flammula]]'' or ''[[Atropa belladonna]]'' :Barrenwort - ''[[Epimedium]]'', especially ''Epimedium alpinum''. :Bearwort - ''[[Meum athamanticum]]'' :[[Bellwort]] - ''[[Uvularia]]'' or [[Campanulaceae]]. :[[Birthwort]] - ''[[Aristolochia]]''. Also, birthroot (''[[Trillium erectum]]''). :[[Birthwort]] - [[Aristolochiaceae]], the birthwort family. :Bishop's wort - ''[[Stachys officinalis]]''. Also, fennel flower. :[[Bitterwort]] - ''[[Gentian]]a lutea''. :[[Bladderwort]] - ''[[Utricularia]]'' ([[aquatic plants]]). :Blawort - A flower, commonly called harebell. Also, a certain plant bearing blue flowers. :[[bloodroot|Bloodwort]] - Sanguinaria Canadensis, a member of [[Papaveraceae]], as are poppies. Produces [[escharotic]] [[alkaloids]] that corrode skin, leaving wounds. Also: ''redroot'', ''bloodroot'', or ''tetterwort''. :[[Cynoglossum omphalodes|Blue navelwort]] - A species of the genus ''[[Cynoglossum]]''. :[[throatwort|Blue Throatwort]] - ''[[Trachelium caeruleum]]''. :Blushwort - A member of the [[gentian]] family. Shame flower. :Bogwort - The [[bilberry]] or [[Vaccinium myrtillus|whortleberry]]. :Bollockwort - A [[Middle English]] name for some types of [[Orchidaceae|orchid]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/21112|title=bollock, n. and adj.|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Oxford English Dictionary]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-19|subscription=yes}}</ref> :Boragewort - Any plant of the [[borage]] family, [[Boraginaceae]]. :[[Filipendula ulmaria|Bridewort]] - ''Filipendula ulmaria''. The common [[meadowsweet]]. Also species of ''[[Spirea]]''.<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web|title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN?url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |archivedate=2015-01-25 |df= }}</ref> :Brimstonewort - Same as ''sulphurwort''. :[[Brotherwort]] - [[Wild Thyme|Wild thyme]]. :Brownwort - ''Scrophularia vernalis''. Yellow figwort. :Bruisewort - Any plant considered to be useful in treating bruises, as herb Margaret. :[[Bullwort]] - ''[[Ammi majus]]''. Bishop's wood. :Bullock's or Cow's [[Lungwort]] - ''[[Verbascum thapsus]]'', the common [[Verbascum|Mullein]]. :[[Burstwort]] - ''[[Herniaria glabra]]''. Formerly used to treat rupture. :[[Butterwort]] - ''[[Pinguicula vulgaris]]''. Other species of ''[[Pinguicula]]'' have "butterwort" in their English names.<ref name=BSBI07/> :[[Cancerwort]] - ''[[Linaria]] vulgaris''. [[Linaria|Toadflax]]. :Catwort - A plant of the genus ''[[Nepeta]]''. [[Catnip]]. :Clown's Ringwort - plant featured in the 1605 panel of the [[New World Tapestry]]. :[[Colewort]] - ''[[Brassica oleracea]]''. [[Cabbage]]. :[[Coralwort]] - [[Lathraea squamaria|Tooth violet]]. :[[Crosswort]] - ''[[Eupatorium perfoliatum]]''. ''[[Lysimachia quadrifolia]]''. Boneset. Also, maywort, a species of ''[[Galium]]'', and species of ''[[Phuopsis]]''. :[[Damewort]] - ''[[Hesperis matronalis]]''. Dame's violet or damask violet or rocket. :[[Danewort]] - ''[[Sambucus ebulus]]''. The dwarf elder. Also, daneweed. :[[Dragonwort]] - An ''[[Artemisia (genus)|Artemisia]]'', or ''Polygonum bistorta''. :[[Filipendula vulgaris|Dropwort]] - ''[[Filipendula vulgaris]]''. A European herb. :[[Dungwort]] - ''[[Helleborus foetidus]]''. Stinking hellebore. :[[Ebony spleenwort]] - ''Fern.'' :[[Elderwort]] - ''[[Sambucus ebulus]]''. :European [[Pillwort]] - ''[[Pilularia globulifera]]''. Peppergrass. :[[Felonwort]] - ''[[Solanum dulcamara]]''. Felonwood or bittersweet. :Feltwort - Another common name for the [[Verbascum|Mullein]], the genus ''Verbascum''. :[[Felwort]] - A common name for various species of [[gentian]]. :[[Triosteum|Feverwort]] - [[Horse gentian]]. :[[Figwort]] - Some plants in the family [[Scrophulariaceae]], including ''[[Euphrasia officinalis]]'' (eyebright); ''[[Veronica officinalis]]'' (speedwell or fluellen); ''Veronica anagullis'' (water speedwell); ''[[Gratiola officinalis]]'' (herb of grace) (hedge [[hyssop]]); ''[[Herpestis monniera]]'' (water hyssop); ''[[Scoparia dulcis]]'' (sweet broomweed), or ''Ilysanthes riparia'' (false [[pimpernel]]). Also the Cape figwort, ''[[Phygelius capensis]]''.<ref name=BSBI07/> :[[Fleawort]] - A [[Plantago|plantain]]. Also some [[Asteraceae|composites]], such as the [[Marsh Fleawort]]. :[[Flukewort]] - ''[[Hydrocotyle vulgaris]]''. :French or golden [[lungwort]] - ''[[Hieracium murorum]]''. :Frostwort - ''[[Helianthemum]] canadenes''. Frostweed or rockrose. :[[Fumewort]] - Genus ''[[Corydalis]]''. :Galewort - ''[[Myrica gale]]''. Sweet gale. :[[Garlicwort]] - ''[[Garlic mustard|Alliaria officinalis]]''. The hedge garlic. :[[Gentianwort]] - Any plant of the family [[Gentianaceae]]. :German [[Madwort]] - ''[[Asperugo procumbens]]''. :[[Gipsywort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Lycopus]]'', as ''[[Lycopus europaeus]]''. Gipsy herb. :[[Glasswort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Salicornia]]''.<ref name=BSBI07/> Frog grass. Also, a [[seaweed]] yielding [[kelp]]. :Golden ragwort - ''[[Senecio aureus]]''. Squawweed. :[[Goutwort]] - ''[[Aegopodium podagraria]]''. Acheweed; Herb Gerard; Goat's foot; Bishop weed; [[Goutweed]]. :Greater [[Spearwort]] - ''Ranunculus lingua''. :Gutwort - ''Globularia alypum''. Used as a purgative. :[[Hammerwort]] - ''[[Parietaria officinalis]]''. The plant [[pellitory (disambiguation)|pellitory]]. :[[Hartwort]] - Any of certain plants of the genera ''Seseli'', ''Tordylium'', and ''[[Bupleurum]]''. :[[Heathwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Erica]]'', the heath family. :Hemlock Dropwort - ''Oenanthe fistulosa''. A plant of the [[parsley]] family, [[Apiaceae]] or Umbelliferae. :[[Hillwort (disambiguation)|Hillwort]] - Wild thyme, or ''[[Mentha pulegium]]'', a kind of pennyroyal. :[[Hogwort]] - ''[[List of Croton species|Croton capitatus]]''. [[J.K. Rowling]] named [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]] after this plant (although she misspelled it). :Holewort - Hollowwort. ''[[Corydalis]] cava''. :[[Honewort]] - A plant used as a remedy for hone. :[[Cerinthe|Honeywort]] - A bee plant of the genus ''[[Cerinthe]]''. :[[Hoodwort]] - ''[[Scutellaria lateriflora]]''. Also called [[Scutellaria|skullcap]] and madweed. :[[Hornwort]] - plants in the genus ''[[Ceratophyllum]]'', such as [[Rigid Hornwort]].<ref name=BSBI07/> :[[Ironwort]] - A plant of the genus ''[[Sideritis]]''. :Kelpwort - ''[[Macrocystis pyrifera]]'', a kind of glasswort. :[[Kidneywort]] - ''[[Cotyledon umbilicus]]''. Also called pennywort and navelwort. :[[Knotwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Illecebrum]]''. :[[Laserwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Laserpitium]]''. :[[Lazarwort]] - [[Laserwort]]. :[[Leadwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Plumbago]]''. :Lesser [[Spearwort]] - ''[[Ranunculus flammula]]''. [[Banewort]]. :[[Lichwort]] - The wall [[Pellitory of the Wall|pellitory]], ''[[Parietaria officinalis]]''. :Lilywort - A plant of the genus ''[[Funkia]]''. Day lily. Also, any plant of the genus Liliaceae. :Liverwort - Any species of [[Marchantiophyta]], a division of non-vascular plants (a type of bryophyte). Also, plants that resemble the liverworts; as, liverleaf (''[[Hepatica]]''). :[[Lousewort]] - ''[[Pedicularis canadensis]]''. Cockscomb; head betony; wood betony (herb Christopher). Any plant of the genus ''[[Pedicularis]]'', as ''[[Pedicularis palustris]]'' (marsh lousewort). :[[Lungwort]] - A plant of the genus ''[[Mertensia]]'', the lungworts. Also, a boraginaceous plant of the genus ''[[Pulmonaria]]''. :[[Lustwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Drosera]]''; the sundew. :[[Madderwort]] - Any plant of the madder family, [[Rubiaceae]]. :[[Madwort]] - ''Alyssum saxitile''. Gold-dust. :Maidenhair [[spleenwort]] - ''[[Asplenium trichomanes]]'' :[[Mallowwort]] - Any plant of the mallow family, [[Malvaceae]]. :[[Marsh Pennywort]] - ''[[Hydrocotyle vulgaris]]''. :Marsh [[St.-John's-wort]] - ''Elodes virginica''. :Marshwort - ''Vaccinium Oxycoccus'', the creeping cranberry. Also, a European umbelliferous plant. :[[Masterwort]] - ''[[Peucedanum]]'' (formerly ''Imperatoria'') ''Ostruthium'' or ''[[Astrantia major]]''. Also, in the [[United States]], ''[[Heracleum lanatum]]'', the cow parsnip. :Maudlinwort - ''[[Leucanthemum vulgare]]''. :Maywort - Bedstraw or mugweed. A species of ''[[Galium]]''. Also, [[Lysimachia quadrifolia|crosswort]], ''[[Lysimachia]] quadrifolia''. :[[Meadowwort]] - A variety of [[meadowsweet]]. :[[Milkwort]] - [[Polygalaceae]], the milkwort family, one of which yields '''buaze'''. ''[[Polygala vulgaris]]'' is the milkwort of [[Europe]]. :[[Miterwort]] or Mitrewort (British) - Bishop's cap. Any plant of the genus ''Mitella''. :[[Moneywort]] - Loosestrife. Herb twopence, an evergreen trailing plant. A popular name for various plants of the genus ''[[Lysimachia]]'', especially ''Lysimachia nummularia'', of the primrose family, [[Primulaceae]]. :[[Moonwort]] - Honesty, a herb of the genus ''[[Lunaria]]''. Also, any fern of the genus ''[[Botrychium]]''. :[[Motherwort]] - A herb, ''[[Leonurus cardiaca]]'', of the mint family, [[Lamiaceae]]. Also, [[mugwort]]. :Mountain [[spiderwort]] - ''Lloydia serotina''. :Mudwort - ''[[Limosella aquatica]]'', found growing in muddy places. :[[Mugwort]] - ''[[Artemisia vulgaris]]''. :Mulewort - Any plant of the genus ''Hemionitis''. :[[Paronychia (plant)|Nailwort]] - Any species of ''[[Paronychia (plant)|Paronychia]]''. Also ''[[Draba verna]]'', ''Saxifraga tridactylites''. :[[Navelwort]] - Plants in the genera ''Cotyledon'' and ''Omphalodes''. :[[Nettlewort]] - Any plant of the nettle family, [[Urticaceae]]. :[[Nipplewort]] - ''Lapsana communis''. :[[Peachwort]] - Lady's Thumb, ''[[Polygonum persicaria]]''. :[[Sagina|Pearlwort]] - Pearl grass; pearl plant; any species of the genus ''Sagina.'' :[[Pennywort]]<!--note: should link to this disambiguation page--> - ''[[Linaria cymbalaria]]''. Also, any one of a number of peltate-leaved plants. Watercup; trumpetleaf. Also Gotu Kola (''[[Centella asiatica]]'') and species from genus ''Hydrocotyle''. :[[Lepidium|Pepperwort]] - ''[[Lepidium latifolium]]''; ''[[Lepidium campestre]]''; Spanish cress, ''[[Lepidium cardamines]]''. Peppergrass; cockweed; dittander; ''[[Marsilea minuta]]'' :[[Peterwort]] - Saint Peter's wort. :[[Pilewort]] - [[Lesser celandine]]. :[[Pipewort]] - ''[[Eriocaulon]]''. :[[Isoëtes|Quillwort]] - ''[[Isoetes]]'', of the quillwort family; certain seedless plants or "fern allies". :[[Quinsywort]] - ''Asperula cynanchica''. :Common ragwort - ''[[Jacobaea vulgaris]]'', and some other plants of the genus ''[[Jacobaea]]'' (once called cankerweed). :Rattlewort - Rattlebox, ''[[Crotalaria]] sagittalis''. :[[Plantago lanceolata|Ribwort]] - ''Plantago lanceolata''. Hen plant. English plantain, the common plantain introduced into the [[United States]] from [[Europe]]. :Rosewort - A plant of the rose family, [[Rosaceae]]. Also, roseroot, ''[[Rhodiola rosea]]'', whose root has the fragrance of a rose. :[[Rupturewort]] - ''Alternanthera polygonoides''. Also species of ''[[Herniaria]]'', such as [[Smooth Rupturewort]], ''H. glabra''. :[[Saltwort]] - A vague and indefinite name applied to any halophyte of the genus ''Salsola''. ''Salsola kali'' is the prickly saltwort. Also, some species of ''Salicornia'', the [[glasswort]]s, are called saltworts. :[[Arenaria (plant)|Sandwort]] - A plant of the genus ''Arenaria''. One of the Caryophyllaceae. :[[Saw-wort|Sawwort]] - A plant of the genus ''Serratula'', especially ''[[Serratula tinctoria]]''. Also, plants in the genus ''[[Saussurea]]''. :Scorpionwort - either ''Ornithopus scorpioides'' or scorpion grass, the [[forget-me-not]]. :[[Scurvywort]] - [[Lesser celandine]]. :Sea [[Lungwort]] - ''Mertensia maritima''. :Sea [[Milkwort]] - Of the primrose family, [[Primulaceae]]. :Sea ragwort - Dusty miller, ''[[Jacobaea maritima]]''. :[[Sea Sandwort]] - A plant of the North Atlantic seacoast. :Sea [[Starwort]] - ''Aster Tripolium''. :Setterwort - ''[[Hellebore|Helleborus]] foetidus''. Pegroots; setter grass; bear's foot. :Sicklewort - ''[[Prunella vulgaris]]'', the healall. :Sleepwort - [[Lettuce]], especially ''[[Lactuca virosa]]'' :[[Slipperwort]] - A plant of the genus ''[[Calceolaria]]''. :[[Sneezewort]] - ''[[Achillea ptarmica]]''. Goosetongue; Bastard pellitory. :[[Soapwort]] - One of the ''bruiseworts''. :[[Sparrowwort]] - A general name for the plants of the genus ''[[Passerina (plant)|Passerina]]'' :[[Spearwort]] - A plant of the genus ''[[Ranunculus]]''. :[[Spiderwort]] - ''[[Tradescantia virginica]]''. Also species in the genus ''[[Commelina]]'', such as [[Blue Spiderwort]], ''C. coelestis''.<ref name=BSBI07/> :[[Spleenwort]] - ''[[Asplenium]]''. A large genus of ferns; formerly used for spleen disorders. :[[Spoonwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Cochlearia]]'', as ''[[Cochlearia officinalis]]''. Scurvy grass. :[[Springwort]] - ''[[Euphorbia lathyris]]''. Caper spurge. :[[Spurwort]] - ''[[Sherardia arvensis]]''. Field madder. :[[Stabwort]] - Wood sorrel, ''[[Oxalis acetosella]]''. :[[Staggerwort]] - Same as [[Jacobaea vulgaris|Staverwort]] . :[[Staithwort]] - Same as [[Cabbage|colewort]]. :Standerwort - Standergrass, ''[[Orchis mascula]]''. :[[Starwort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Aster (genus)|Aster]]''. :Staverwort - Staggerwort; ragwort, ''[[Jacobaea vulgaris]]''. :[[Stinkwort]]<!--not an error to link to this disambiguation page--> – Various plants including ''[[Helleborus foetidus]]'', the stinking hellebore; ''[[Dittrichia graveolens]]'' and ''[[Inula graveolens]]''; and ''[[Datura stramonium]]'', jimson weed. :[[Stitchwort]]<!--not an error to link to this disambiguation page--> - Any of several plants of the genus ''[[Stellaria]]''. Stichwort. :St. James' Wort - ''[[Senecio jacobaea]]'' or ''[[Senecio aureus]]'', two species of [[Senecio|ragwort]]. :[[St. John's Wort]] - Can refer to any species of ''[[Hypericum]]''. :[[Stonewort]] - A general name for plants of the genus ''[[Chara (alga)|Chara]]'' and ''[[Nitella]]''; [[water horsetail]]. :St. Paul's Wort – species of the genus ''[[Sigesbeckia]]'', such as [[Eastern St Paul's-wort]], ''Sigesbeckia orientalis''.<ref name=BSBI07/> :[[St. Peter's Wort]] - Any plant of the genus ''[[Ascyrum]], such as'' ''[[Hypericum quadrangulum (disambiguation)|Hypericum quadrangulum]]''. The cowslip. :Strapwort - ''[[Corrigiola litoralis]]''. :Sulphurwort - ''[[Peucedanum officinale]]''. Hog fennel. :[[Swallowwort (disambiguation)|Swallowwort]] - The [[Greater Celandine]], ''Chelidonium majus''. Also, any plant of the genus ''[[Asclepias]]'' or ''[[Cynanchum]]''. [[Black Swallow-wort]] is ''[[Vincetoxicum nigrum]]''.<ref name=BSBI07/> :Sweetwort - Any plant of a sweet taste. :[[Talewort]] - ''[[Borago officinalis]]''. Formerly considered a valuable remedy. :[[Tetterwort]] - According to 1913 Webster's Dictionary, ''Chelidonium majus'' in England or ''[[Bloodroot|Sanguinaria canadensis]]'' in the Americas. A wort plant used to treat tetter. :[[Thoroughwort]] - ''[[Eupatorium perfoliatum]]''. Boneset. :[[Throatwort]] - A name for one or two plants of the genus ''[[Campanula]]''. :[[Thrumwort]] - ''[[Amaranthus caudatus]]''; velvet flower or [[Amaranthus caudatus|love-lies-bleeding]]. :[[Toothwort]] - ''[[Lathraea squamaria]]'' and ''[[Lathraea clandestina]]''; also ''[[Cardamine|Dentaria diphylla]]''. [[Crinkleroot]] or [[Cardamine diphylla|Pepper Root]]. :Towerwort - the tower mustard and some allied species of ''[[Arabis]]''. :[[Lobaria pulmonaria|Tree lungwort]] - ''[[Lobaria pulmonaria]]'', a [[lichen]]. :Trophywort - The Indian cress; [[Nasturtium (common name)|nasturtium]], ''Tropaeolum majus''. :[[Venus's-navelwort]] - Either blue navelwort or white navelwort. :[[Wall Pennywort]] - ''[[Umbilicus rupestris]]''. :Wartwort - [[Euphorbia helioscopia]] An attractive European weed which has flowers that turn towards the sun. :[[Water dropwort]] - ''Oenanthe fistulosa, Oenanthe phellandrum'', or any plant of that genus. :[[Water Figwort]] - Water betony. :Water Pennywort - ''[[Hydrocotyle]]''; marsh pennyworts. :Water [[Starwort]] - ''Callitriche verna'', of the water-milfoil family, and other species of the genus ''[[Callitriche]]'', such as [[Common Water-starwort]], ''Callitriche stagnalis''. :[[Waterwort]] - An aquatic plant of the genus ''[[Elatine]]''. Any plant of the family Philydraceae. :[[White navelwort]] - A plant of the genus ''[[Omphalodes]]''. :White [[Vincetoxicum officinale|Swallowwort]] - ''Vincetoxicum officinale''. :Willowwort - Any plant of the [[Willow|willow family]], [[Salicaceae]]. A species of ''[[Lythrum]]''. Grasspoly; a variety of loosestrife. :[[Woundwort (disambiguation)|Woundwort]] - The name of several plants of the genus ''[[Stachys]]'', a genus of labiate plants. Also, ''[[Anthyllis vulneraria]]''. :[[Yellow starwort]] - Elecampane, ''[[Inula helenium]]''. :[[Yellow-wort]] - ''[[Chlora perfoliata]]'', [[Gentianaceae]]
==References== <references/>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Lists of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' monsters}} This is intended to be a comprehensive list of creatures that have appeared in various ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' works. Each individual list covers a span of years by edition of the game, with monsters being listed chronologically by book in which they appeared.
Although efforts have been made to include all creatures, there are likely to be omissions and other errors. At any particular time, there will be variations in the level of brief detail, and there are some duplications, not all of which are errors as there are some name duplications amongst the creatures.
==Original ''Dungeons & Dragons''== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons monsters (1974–1976)}} The original edition of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' consisted of a boxed set by [[Gary Gygax]] and [[Dave Arneson]] printed in 1974, and several pamphlet-sized supplements printed through 1976. The volume "Monsters & Treasure" in the original set, and the supplements (''[[Greyhawk]]'', ''[[Blackmoor (supplement)|Blackmoor]]'' and ''[[Eldritch Wizardry]]'') included a section of monsters.
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons monsters (1974–1976)#TSR 2002 - Dungeons & Dragons "white box" (1974)|TSR 2002 – Dungeons & Dragons "white box" (1974)]]''
==Basic ''Dungeons & Dragons''== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons monsters (1977–1999)}} This edition of Dungeons & Dragons began in 1981, as a revision of the introductory ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set]]'' established it as a separate version of the game that ran concurrently with both 1st edition and 2nd edition ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' until the line was ended in 1994. The Basic Rulebook collected many of the monsters from the previous D&D supplements, and the subsequent ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set|Basic Set]]'', ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Expert Set|Expert Set]]'', ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Companion Set|Companion Set]]'', ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Master Rules|Master Set]]'', and ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Immortals Rules|Immortals Set]]'' all added more new monsters to the game. The [[Creature Catalogue]] expanded on these sets even further, collecting monsters that had appeared in basic D&D modules and adding new monsters as well.
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons monsters (1977–1999)#TSR 2001 - Dungeons & Dragons - Basic Rulebook (1977)|TSR 2001 – Dungeons & Dragons – Basic Rulebook (1977)]]''
==''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' 1st edition== {{main|Index of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st edition monsters}} Introduced in 1977, the ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' game built upon the original edition of ''D&D''. This edition also introduced the concept of a ''[[Monster Manual]]'', a separate book to deal with just monsters. The original ''Monster Manual'' collected the monsters from the original D&D books, and other sources, and expanded on the monster format. The original ''Fiend Folio'' and ''Monster Manual II'' were also printed during the run of ''AD&D'' 1st edition, and numerous monsters appeared in other modules and game supplements at the time.
*''[[Index of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st edition monsters#TSR 2009 - Monster Manual (1977)|TSR 2009 – Monster Manual (1977)]]'' *''[[Index of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st edition monsters#TSR 2012 - Fiend Folio (1981)|TSR 2012 – Fiend Folio (1981)]]'' *''[[Index of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st edition monsters#TSR 2016 - Monster Manual II (1983)|TSR 2016 – Monster Manual II (1983)]]''
==''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition''== {{main|List of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition monsters}} Initially, the 2nd edition of ''AD&D'' replaced the idea of a hardbound ''Monster Manual'' with a loose-leaf ''[[Monstrous Compendium]]'' series that eventually numbered 14 volumes. These volumes greatly expanded the detail level on the previous edition's monsters, and returned most of the 1st edition monsters to the game. Due to popular demand (as the format was considered too fragile and unwieldy), the ''Monstrous Compendium'' series eventually ended and was replaced with the 384-page ''[[Monstrous Manual]]'' in 1993, which reprinted many of the creatures previously featured in the ''Monstrous Compendium'' series. This book was followed up by four ''Monstrous Compendium Annuals'' in the following years, and many new monsters were introduced in game modules and supplements throughout 2nd edition.
*''[[List of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition monsters#TSR 2102 - MC1 - Monstrous Compendium Volume One (1989)|TSR 2102 – MC1 – Monstrous Compendium Volume One (1989)]]'' *''[[List of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition monsters#TSR 2103 - MC2 - Monstrous Compendium Volume Two (1989)|TSR 2103 – MC2 – Monstrous Compendium Volume Two (1989)]]'' *''[[List of Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd edition monsters#TSR 2140 - Monstrous Manual (1993)|TSR 2140 – Monstrous Manual (1993)]]''
==''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3rd edition== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition monsters}} A new ''Monster Manual'' was published in 2000 as part of the core rulebooks for ''D&D'' 3rd edition. The monster format was greatly altered to match the new edition. Just like with 1st edition, this edition included a ''Fiend Folio'' and ''Monster Manual II'', and debuted many new monsters in various game supplements.
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition monsters#TSR 11552 – Monster Manual (2000)|TSR 11552 – Monster Manual (2000)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition monsters#WTC 88268 - Monster Manual II (2002)|WTC 88268 – Monster Manual II (2002)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition monsters#WTC 88661 - Fiend Folio (2003)|WTC 88661 – Fiend Folio (2003)]]''
==''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3.5 edition== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons 3.5 edition monsters}} The version 3.5 rules included a revision of the 3rd edition ''Monster Manual'', and continued the ''Monster Manual'' series with books III-V. As with previous versions of the game, a number of new monsters debuted in a variety of game supplements in this era.
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3.5 edition monsters#WTC 17755 - Monster Manual (2003)|WTC 17755 – Monster Manual (2003)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3.5 edition monsters#WTC 17921 - Monster Manual III (2004)|WTC 17921 – Monster Manual III (2004)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3.5 edition monsters#WTC 9537672 - Monster Manual IV (2006)|WTC 9537672 – Monster Manual IV (2006)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 3.5 edition monsters#WTC 9568172 - Monster Manual V (2007)|WTC 9568172 – Monster Manual V (2007)]]''
==''Dungeons & Dragons'' 4th edition== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition monsters}}
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition monsters#WTC 21720 - Monster Manual (2008)|WTC 21720 – Monster Manual (2008)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition monsters#239667200 - Monster Manual 2 (2009)|239667200 – Monster Manual 2 (2009)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition monsters#253840000 - Monster Manual 3 (2010)|253840000 – Monster Manual 3 (2010)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition monsters#244650000 - Monster Vault (2010)|244650000 – Monster Vault (2010)]]''
==''Dungeons & Dragons'' 5th edition== {{main|List of Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition monsters}}
*''[[List of Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition monsters#A92180000 - Monster Manual (2014)|A92180000 – Monster Manual (2014)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons &_Dragons 5th edition monsters#B86820000 - Volo's Guide to Monsters (2016)|B86820000 – Volo's Guide to Monsters (2016)]]'' *''[[List of Dungeons &_Dragons 5th edition monsters#C45940000_-_Mordenkainen's_Tome_of_Foes_(2018)|C45940000 – Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes (2018)]]''
